reviewText:
So I grew up around real-life pinball tables yet never spent much time on them.  The reason is that I had 'better' things to do at the arcade: Space Invaders, Asteroids, Galaga, Paperboy, Double Dragon, etc. were all more important to me than pinball.  But this game has me wishing that wasn't the case! In fact, if I had a time machine I would go back and try all of those tables in real life!

I know I haven't said much about the game itself, and I'm not going to either.  The truth is I don't even know much about pinball.  I'll just give you a couple reasons why I think this game is such a success to me:

--each table feels genuinely different which adds to replayability

--the leaderboard system is great: it got me to add friends for chasing high scores and I've also been telling family members to try this out--there's nothing like beating your sister or cousin or even long lost uncle!

--everyone gets a free table, which is a pretty good one in and of itself (just try it!)

--love the sound bytes (especially for Star Wars tables) as they really add to the overall atmosphere

--it's still fun even if your not very good at it (like me)

--it got me to write this review

reviewText:
Beautiful game let down heavily by the studio who created it. Zen Studios just doesn't listen at all to the community and is by now just a simple money making machine, going for lucrative license projects. So many things are missing that could make this game a lot better on especially the PC tablet form factor but Zen is not at all interested in improving the basic framework. They'd rather churn out new tables and keep rolling in $$$.

Also worth noting is the blatant deleting of all the high scores.. randomly and without asking the community. Extremely annoying especially for the people who put hundreds of hours on the game.

You'll be slightly better off with Pinball Arcade (though Far Sight, the developer, is not much better than Zen. Their coding platform is a buggy mess and they just do not seem all that talented). Best option is to get VisualPinball or the new Unity pinball 3D thing which seems very promising.

reviewText:
Ever since I was a young boy, I played the silver ball.  No, wait, I'm thinking of Tommy.  Either way, pinball has been an important part of my life whenever it has been.  Time marches on though, and you can't just go play pinball like you used to.  Down at the local hangout, by the soda fountain, with flippers flipping, balls always bouncing, to the left and to the right, lights flashing, eplileptic kids flailing about on the floor, those days, back then, they're gone.

All is not lost though.  Pinball FX2 is here to fill that void left by the demise of the pinball machine with software pinball that surpasses the original in every way except for those it does not.  When it comes down to it, what you really lose is having an actual pinball table in front of you.  You can never recreate that exact feel, the solid wood gripped firmly in your hands as you aim for ever higher scores while deftly avoiding the flailing epileptic kids.

That's just the way it has to be though, and there are plenty of good things about virtual pinball that makes it well worth a play.  The tables can be more elaborate than a real pinball table ever could, and they certainly are lovely to look at.  Any pinball table you want is right there on your television, no need for a huge arcade to house all of your games.  Heck, with a wireless xbox controller, you even get some vibration when you shake the table.

If you loved pinball when you were a kid, or know someone who did, give Pinball FX2 a try.  It's the next best thing to being there again, reliving those memories, and best of all, you won't have to step over any epileptics to do it.

reviewText:
Zen Studios did a great favor to all the digital pinball enthusiasts - they didn't go for a simulation.

Let me explain it before I get back in the game. You can always try to be more realistic, more physics-respecting, more simulating game. And you will probably fail miserably because there's a sweet magic of analogue mechanisms of pinball machines no computer will be able to understand and process... EVER.

BUT... if you take a concept of pinball game which says 'keep that ball up for as long as possible and score as many points as you possibly can', slap it on crazy fun tables with various themes and make playing digital pinball FUN thing to do, either solo or with friends - yes, you will be coming back for one more and yes, you will never stop.

So, thank you, Zen Studios for nothing making Pinball FX2 mediocre simulation pinball game, but a super fun arcade pinball game.

reviewText:
At launch, Pinball FX 2 was already a fantastic game. Originally released on the Xbox 360, it featured backwards compatibility with the original Pinball FX, and this allowed an already burgeoning title to be filled with even more Pinball goodness. As it stands, there are over 30 tables in the game as of this writing, and each and every one is free to try, with the standout Sorcerer's Lair being completely free.

It's a little sad knowing that the arcade is no longer truly viable, and I'll never again experience the giddy joy of pumping coins into a table, longing for the extra ball and multiball modes we all love, or watching to see if the numbers matched and I won a free game. But while the arcade as a destination may be on it's final legs, the pinball experience presented in FX 2 is pure unadulterated joy.

Those fond memories are brought to the forefront with this version, the ultimate version of Pinball FX 2. As a free download, this game should find a place in just about every gamer's library, and with tables based on many themes, there are sure to be some you'll love. Each table has their own achievements, backstory, missions, combos, and design.

For most of the tables, the cost is approximate to what would cost a single game of pinball at the arcade, so value wise the game is excellent value. The hours upon hours of gameplay possibility and replayability is enormous, and there really is something for everyone here - from Ancient Rome to Boba Fett.

In addition, the table design is above and beyond what can be done with conventional pinball, with full video mini games and hidden extras. Nothing is truly over the top, though there aren't any dead spots either. With seven angles to play from, and a free view angle to fly around the table close up, you'll find plenty to play for. Ramps, drop balls, lit targets, missions, and more are available on each table.

Finely integrated leaderboards will see you play against friends and the community on each and every table, with an overall score representing your prowess across all tables. Local leaderboards and multiplayer should see FX 2 become a staple quick fire up and play at home as well.

The sound and graphics are really well done - with the narrator both chastising and egging you on to play better, and with rewarding sound bites when you do well. The sound effects are particularly fantastic on Secrets of the Deep, an underwater themed table, and there are classic themes and sound effects on the Star Wars and Marvel themed tables, respectively.

The game is a joy to watch in action. The design and execution of the tables really cannot be overstated. There are multiple views and options to tune the game to your liking, and the low requirements make this an ideal game for every steam user. Pinball FX 2 is a beautiful game, not just a beautiful pinball game.

Overall this is a game too easy not to enjoy. The low cost and low barrier to entry make this an easy recommend, and the many hours of replayability, the freedom to pick up and play, and just the genuine fun available make this the best virtual pinball title ever made available. It's well worth your time.

9.0/10.

reviewText:
The days when we could go out with a pocket full of change and spend hours on end playing pinball at the arcades are long gone and apart from the odd pinball machine in a pub here and there most of us will have a hard time finding a real machine. If we want to play pinball today we probably have to do it virtually and Pinball FX2 delivers one of the most enjoyable virtual pinball experiences.

I'm pretty sure the basic concept of pinball needs no introduction but just in case you've been living under rock: You use your flippers to direct a small steel ball around the pinball table and aim for different targets to score as many points as possible while at the same time you try to prevent the ball from falling into the drain or one of the side lanes.

Pinball FX2 already offers a variety of tables and new ones are released regularly. All the tables differ widely from each other in terms of gameplay, looks and underlying theme. Some have a somewhat minimalistic layout with only few ramps and extras, others feel almost overloaded with features. Some are easy to get into, others are very challenging and have a steep learning curve. Fans of the Marvel and Star Wars franchises will be delighted to have the opportunity to choose from a selection of acordingly themed tables.

You can compete with friends in local hotseat multiplayer matches or chase highscores to climb up local and online leaderboards but the competion gets most intense with friend score challenges when you have some other players in your Steam friendlist.

The game supports keyboard, mouse and controller.

Unlike Pinball Arcade (another great pinball simulation available right here on Steam), that offers authentic recreations of real-life tables licenced from pinball machine manufacturers, all Pinball FX2 tables are original creations by the games developer Zen Studios. This can be a drawback if you want to relive your pinball memories with your favourite tables from the past but it's also an advantage because it allows for more artistic freedom. A freedom the developers put to good use with stunning effects that wouldn't be physically possible in reality, like Marvel characters battling each other across the table, among other things.

Additional tables come at a decent price, especially if you consider the many hours of entertainment that every single one provides. With the wide variety of genuinely different tables, everyone, casuals and hardcore pinball fanatics alike, will find some tailored to their individual taste. There's really no reason to hesitate to get some pinball action right away.

reviewText:
Why not recommended:I played pinball for years when I was younger (as my dad worked in a bar part-time) and later I went through town to specific pinball tables.

The tables in this game are purely fantasy. They could not be built in real life.
And whats more: You play on a 2D table - and then 3D objects just pop up (like Plants vs. Zombies), which really.. does not match the feeling of a flat pinball table.
Also you can feel that physics is nearly, but not exacly as in real life. Sometimes it feels to fast, then to slow, then you have camera zoom in on an element. All nicely done; all nothing to do with a real pinball table.

So far the best virtual tables I know are still the old TimeShock! and bus driver thingy which name I don't remember right now. They are decades old and still look great; sadly do not come with high res/controller support (which is why I tried this one) and don't work as nicely on some machines due to DOS emulation :-/


Why you might still like it:Pinball tables are nicely designed, have lots of different elements (although some feel generic) and use their specific themed sounds, graphics etc. So if you know the movie/game the table is based on, it does provide a nice ahh

reviewText:
I'm a pretty big fan of pinball. I'm not a big fan at all of Pinball FX and the tables therein. Visually, they're fantastic, but only if you're watching someone else. It's a real pain when Spider Man swings in front of your flippers, or you have massive explosions going off that distract your tracking from the hyper-kinetic ball. Pinball FX is not going for realism or emulating pinball, and is very much invested in maximizing the potential of digital pinball, thus the games feel faster than what you would see in traditional pinball, or even something like The Pinball Arcade. This is usually to the game's detriment, in my eyes.

Personally, I dislike the feel of the game. At no point does the ball feel controllable, and in some instances, the physics are simply wrong or buggy. Drop catches and live catches are rare but seemingly possible; they don't seem like something you can actively do as the technique looks to me more of a strange collision bug than actual skill and timing.  I found myself having less fun playing the game due to inconsistencies in physics reactions, shots not registering, and collision bugs with flippers, ramps, other balls and walls.

Table rules are deeper than necessary, requiring detailed study of the rule sheet. Which, by itself is fine, however there is a bit of an issue when you can't figure out what you need to shoot for due to information not being presented clearly by the game. Firing up a game and learning the rules intrinsically is just not going to happen. Additionally, many modes require simply grinding shots, which to me, is remarkably boring. Coupled with the shot registration bugs, actually working toward a mode or a strategy tends to be more infuriating than it's worth.

Many of the tables borrow shot concepts from existing pinball tables, which is great! However, they seem to only have borrowed the mechanic, but have not paid any attention to ball flow and angle after the fact - many shots are simply drains waiting to happen. You are literally being punished with a ball drain for successfully making a shot. Additionally, some concepts are used, but simply fail to work. For instance, the Venom table looks to attempt the outlane gate nudge-back concept used on Bally's Centaur... which would be amazing if the designers understood that having the bounce post about a mile away from the gate and the sensitivity for tilting cranked on the game makes the gate-save concept useless.

Overall, if you're looking for something different in the pinball space, try a table from Pinball FX, but do so knowing you're going to be playing tables made by people who don't seem to grasp the idea of game layout or rules design.

reviewText:
I've played many real and video pinball machines over the years and, to be totally honest, while the tables in Pinball FX2 are beautiful and make good use of modern video game graphics, there are issues that make the game less than stellar (and even less than playable) in my book.

First and foremost, the flippers are apparently insanely powerful. I've played pinball machines with strong flippers, but these are just impossible. Even on the near end of the flipper, the ball is launched off of it with nearly the same or exactly the same speed as if you flipped it from the distant end. Second, and nearly as bad, is the ball itself has just the most baffling physical properties. When you strike it with the flippers, it feels almost hollow and just flies off, even on top of the flipper hinge, even if you're trying not to even move the ball at all. If you try to catch the ball by holding the flipper when it comes down one of the side lanes, it rolls completely off the end of the flipper, every single time. You can flip it cleanly up a normal ramp and it will stop dead not even an inch up the ramp as if it lost momentum from spinning/rubbing against the side of the ramp, but then it comes straight back at nearly the same speed it had when you struck it (which is to say, maximum speed, because it always seems to be moving very fast), almost like you flipped it up a 60° incline with no friction at all. This happens in exceedingly random fashion as well; you can hit the same ramp at the same speed and it can go up normally...or not. There doesn't appear to be any rhyme or reason to it.

Now, those things on their face make the game unplayable for me. If the underlying physics of the game engine behaved in a predictable way, it might have been different. The table designs themselves look pretty nice. That said, the dichotomy between the free table's design features that are reminiscent of actual pinball machine designs from the 90's and the essentially impossible design features that are only possible because it's a video game are a bit off-putting. I would prefer a table that's designed one way or the other. Especially if I'm going to be asked to put my initials into the Sorcerer's Lair table with the flipper buttons like some kind of non-keyboard-having troglodyte, a table that if it existed in reality would have to be LITERALLY haunted in order to have the same kinds of display features. The camera could use some work too, and yes, I tried all of the different view settings, none of them really helped me, especially when it came to trying to gauge distance on skill shots.

Given the amount of graphical polish in the game, I really have to wonder how it ended up being this way. I was excited to try the game because the tables look beautiful and well designed, but instead I came away with that weird feeling of disappointment mixed with doubt that makes me wonder if I should keep trying it once again to see if my perception was incorrect. Unfortunately, I kept coming away with the same conclusions each time. Well, at least there's a free table.

Edit: Haters gonna hate. I consider the downvotes validation of everything I said, and you should too. Clarified physics complaints slightly and made other minor changes. Moved edit info to bottom.

reviewText:
I did enjoy this game for some time.  Eventually I had purchased a few more additional tables but had not played them yet.  About 2 weeks after purchasing the tables I went to go play them and there was a new EULA with concerns regarding collection of information and advertisements.  Many people posted against the changes and devs said it would be rewritten.  It's been a long time with no change as they've waited for it to just blow over.  As such I feel I must change my review and warn people against supporting this game and its devs.

My old review from April 5, 2015:
I never played much real pinball and never cared for the ones that usually came with windows so I can't really make any comparisons, however I have enjoyed this game so far.   Some things I liked, the initial game is free so you can basically demo it and not have to uninstall/reinstall.  Most of the packs aren't too expensive, I picked up the south park and one of the star wars packs giving me 6 different pinball machines to work with, although I don't much care for the default machine the game gives you for free.  Each machine is configured differently and follows a theme, there are some neat little bonuses that work sort of like mini games, and they also have objectives marked out on the top left to let you know when you've done something right and how to proceed.  All in all I feel a robust 3d pinball game that offers you the choice of your favorite theme and leaderboard for both people on the same computer but steam friends as well.

reviewText:
If I can even convince 1 person to save their money on this title I'd be happy.  (If it was jivjov I'd be ecstatic!)  But in general do not support any Zen Studios products because they are likely to change your legal terms, say anything they want and you'll be forced to agree or lose your money.

HUGE CON:
Zen/Microsoft added a EULA to the title.  That in and of itself isn't the problem.  As long as the EULA was added BEOFRE consumers purchased the title that would be fine.  The problem is that they are holding every license/subscription hostage for all of the EXISTING consumers who owned this title BEFORE the EULA was added.  e.g. They added the EULA a few months ago and consumers are FORCED to agree to it before they can play the title again.  There's been a consistently ongoing discussion about their actions in http://steamcommunity.com/app/226980/discussions/0/620712999988337987.

So do not support an anti-consumer, anti-EU laws, anti-moral compassed company.  They could have easily avoided this issue IF they left FX2 alone and created an FX3 which contained the EULA and let consumer DECIDE.

The worst part is that when directly asked as per the instructions of the EULA, Zen will not disclose what it is they/3rd parties are collecting.


PROS:
Some tables were fun.  Not all.  But at least you could spend about 3 minutes trying each board before you purchased it.



SUGGESTION to Steam & 3rd party Publishers/Developers:
Steam/VALVe should reset the refund clock if a Publisher/Developer adds a EULA to a title AFTER the title has been released.  That way consumers can actually make a choice:
A) 'I accepting your new legal terms' (and letting the publisher keep the spent money)
OR
B) 'I don't agree to your new terms' (and I'll be getting my money back.  You should have had the EULA when I originally purchased the title or learned not to add it post-sale.)

reviewText:
Pinball FX2
Lets all play Pinball FX2, today, tomorrow, and who knows maybe next week and next year and so on. The best way for me to discribe Pinball FX2 is that it has been washed, scrubed and blow dryed and now its been refreshed and revitalised.

I myself like to play Pinball for pure fun and joy and if I get a great score Im happy, but if not then Im still happy I had my few hours enjoyment and satisfaction. I only play Pinball if Im in the right mood anyway, as Im not a pro at it, and nor do I want to be. But I do love and admire all the great scores my friends share on it, and I know they enjoyed thier time playing the game and so earning those genuine and honest fantastic scores.

It takes a great deal of consentration, very good fine motor skills and plenty and I mean plenty of constant practice and patience to become a Pinball King and or Wizard to be the best of the best and we have plenty of fantastic best of the best Pinballers that have put thier hearts and soles and many, many hundreds and thousands of hours into the game to master it and they do it ever so well, and who knows i could become 1 too some day. But Im not going to, because its way out of my league anyway, and Im not as passionate as others are.

With regards to these tables and my personal experiance with these tables, is that I have prefered them over any other Pinball tables that steam has to offer, and thats not ment to put other companys down niether. I personally like and prefere most of Pinball FX tables but some are more prefered and fun than others and we all have our personal favourites and thats fine too.

Im not a Pro Pinball play and so I cant explain the game play as such, just that Pinball is Pinball, and I love these Pinball tables. I am very proud to have some of the much loved best of the best Pinball players as my friends and I hope and pray that they never give up, and keep striving to be the best of the best and perhaps just take much needed breaks as I do when required as breaks are very important in life, they help clear the air and make way for fresh vitalised restarts ;)

Dont give up on Pinball FX, give the game a go. The game is not easy, nor is it difficult as such, and it may not be for everyone. But the game sure is a lot of fun if you can get into it. I cant get the big scores, but it sure is fun trying to achieve and aim for your next more improved score anyway.

Im going to give Pinball FX2 a 9/10

If you dont agree, thats fine too.

reviewText:
I love playing FX2 Pinball!

BUT…….

!!! WARNING !!!

Please be aware that, even though the Store Page makes no mention, every Zen Studios FX2 Pinball table or package you buy is actually “early access”, and as such is almost guaranteed to not only have bugs (not just on new tables, but also old and unfixed bugs on tables well over a year old), but most tables continue to generate a more or less constant stream of new bug issues (over 200 since 10/2015.) Zen does little or nothing to notify players when (or IF) problems are ever resolved. I have more than 825 games, yet Zen Studios, FX2 Pinball remains one of the worst, least responsive, most deliberately unpleasant and obtuse Steam vendors I’ve had the displeasure to encounter. I have gone from quite certainly being among the MOST supportive of FX2 players, to perhaps the MOST bitterly disappointed.

And if you raise questions, be prepared to be treated as enemy"

reviewText:
A  lot of FUD being slung here
I have to wonder how many of those slinging FUD are ones that were banned for cheating, because if you actually READ the EULA It spells everything out quite clearly..if you wanna have access to the leaderboards? You use the latest client...that's it. No secret spying, none of the BS being slung by the reviews here, simply you can't use old clients if you want to put your name on the leaderboards. Considering every other time I've seen such a thing it was because  they were having serious issues with pirates and hacked game clients? I think we can all guess who is doing the FUD slinging.

As for the game itself? in a word FUN with a capital F! The tables are great, with so many mini-games and cool animations the first few times you play you'll lose because you were too busy gawking at all the cool stuff, its a real blast. Great physics, fair tables, you'll wish you could get real life tables that can do what these do!

EULA says ZEN will distribute your personal data to 3rd parties and cannot be held liable for what the 3rd parties do with your information.

http://blog.zenstudios.com/privacy_policy_pc_steam.html

6. THIRD PARTY TERMS AND CONDITIONS

Please note that your access to and use of the ZEN Services may be subject to certain third party terms and conditions and ZEN is not liable for any such third parties’ use of your personal data.

Please note that in accordance with the valid license agreements concluded by ZEN in some cases ZEN may be obliged to share with its licensors all and any user data (including personal data) that ZEN collects through any of the ZEN Services using the license provided by the licensor in the same form and format as such user data is actually collected.

Certain ZEN Services that ZEN may offer, such as multiplayer gaming, social networking and gaming console services, may use third party services to provide authentication for the ZEN Services with a gaming console ID, social networking ID, or gaming network account. In connection with such use, certain personally identifiable user and/or membership data may be transferred automatically to and from ZEN.

ZEN may disclose your personal data to third parties in connection with a corporate merger, consolidation, restructuring, the sale of substantially all of ZEN’s stock and/or assets or other corporate change, including, without limitation, during the course of any due diligence process provided, however, that this Privacy Policy shall continue to govern such personal data.

reviewText:
I have played alot of pinball in my life, starting with real pin tables in the 1960s. I buy every pinball game I can find, regardless of platform. Pinball FX2 is perhaps the very best virtual pinball game that I have ever played. Let it be known though that there are currently 57 tables available on Steam counting all 8 Super League Football (Soccer) team variants, and I own them all. On October 21st of this year they will release four more tables in a pack. More on those tables in a moment.

Unlike many virtual pinball games the table designs and ball physics are rock-solid. Approx. 30% of their tables are totally original, as in non-licensed. My personal favorite of these is Socerer's Lair. In the interest of completness my least favorite of these is V12, but it may be just me as it's really hard for me to score well on this table. There are two South Park tables, which I love. My favorite is South Park's Super Sweet Pinball. I can spend hours playing that one. There is also a Portal table, which some gamers think of as Portal 3, because it takes place after the events of Portal 2. There is also a table based on The Walking Dead and one, which I love alot, based on the video game franchise Splosion Man. Well, more closely on the second game in the series Ms. Splosion Man, which is what it's called. It has a very anime feel to it that I like. It also reminds me abit of the Sega game for the Dreamcast Space Channel 5.

Disney must love Zen Studios, as approx. 60% of the tables are either based on Star Wars or on Marvel comics and/or films and TV series. Zen recently renewed their licensing agreement for both franchises. Overall these tables range from good to excellent. Star Wars Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back is one of the really good ones, with alot of mini-games. Darth Vader has a stand out line in this one - I'm altering the game. Pray I don't alter it further." :)

reviewText:
It's a pretty good game of pinball. Specifically, video game pinball. The physics work pretty well, and the graphics are solid. Very rarely have I encountered a problem while playing. I can only remember one instance of a ball getting stuck because of a bug.

Edit: Something I wanted to point about my video game pinball comment. What I mean is that these tables are designed to be played longer than the real life counterpart(because they want your money of course). Therefore they have more extra balls you can earn, kickbacks and so on. You can even nudge the table in ways you couldn't do in real life, either because of personal injury or damaging the table itself. Be warned though, most tables will only give you two chances in a period of time before tilting out on you, but it sure can be fun to save a ball that otherwise would have been lost.

One last thing that relates to the fact this is video game pinball, when you exit out a game in progress, the game will be saved, so don't worry if something comes up, or if you're just having a really good game but you can't play in one sitting.

The one thing that appeals to me about pinball is that you're always trying to get better, so that you can continue to improve and of course get a better score. One thing that also helps is comparing how well you do with your friends. I have a number of Steam friends just so I can have scores to compare with and try to beat.

I would say overall, the quality of the tables are fantastic. If I have any complaints, it's mostly about the selection-it's that Star Wars and Marvel theme tables dominate the catalog. Now don't get me wrong, I like Star Wars, and I love the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but it would be cool to see different properties more often. (BTW, get Guardians of the Galaxy, and the Star Wars Balance of the Force pack-Starfighter Assault is my favorite table)

I play with my X-Box 360 controller, it works really well with the game.
I also have my second monitor on portrait mode, which makes a huge difference in seeing the table. If you can have that setup I totally recommend it.

I never got to play real pinball that much, there's no arcades where I live, and of course getting a real machine is very expensive, so I think this is a good alternative. And the price for tables is decent.
Also, there is a free table, and you can try all the tables to see what they're like.

I recommend this game. Have fun, and may the bumpers be with you.

reviewText:
I quite like this game. A great many tables to choose from, and you even get the first table for free. (if you want to check it out.)
There are a few tables that are just annoying to play, but most of them can give a satifying feeling of a good game even after the last ball drains.
Pricing per table is not too expensive, but might seem a bit high if you plan on buying all the tables in one go. I recommend starting off with one of the packs, which gives you 4 tables, and buy tables as you go along. And as I've found, returning to old tables after your skill increases, the replay value is there.

3D works great if you've got the gear for it, and at first I only played 3D and anytime I looked at the tables in 2D, they looked flat and strange, and I couldn't play them. Although as my skill increases, the difference between 60hz/eye & 120hz is simply too big, so I play in 2D these days. (atleast untill I can find a monitor that let's me have a high refresh rate for 3D.=)

reviewText:
Whenever I'm upset playing other Steam oh-so-serious games, I run to casuals. PinballFX, honestly, is one of them.

With the game, whether you just want to play the game casually, or to stomp your friends' high score, it's all catered. With tons of tables to play with (woooo thanks Humble Bundle) and well made tables, makes the experience fun.

The gameplay is the same old, you only need to jump directly and play. All you need to do is to keep the ball inside your table and don't let it fall off. But unlike other pinball games I've played, this one offers an in-tables quests depending on where we aim the ball to thus makes the session more interesting to play and achieving higher personal scores isn't like a long mindless grind. And if you ever are confused with the tables, there's a help file (just pause the game and click on help) so you know of the table's objectives and on what to do.

The tables designs are full with vibrant color and light, more than enough to please my eyes. And they're not fully static, with several addons side characters and mini tables (quest result), you're not just seeing a ball bouncing right and left.

The tables are sold separately as 'DLC's. Make sure you read the appropriate store page of each DLC to know how many tables you're getting (yes, some are packaged together as one DLC, so 4 tables-for-one is not surprising). For tables reviews, refer to each Store Page's review, as it's too expansive to be reviewed in this single writing.

Game natively supports local hot seat, but I personally would've liked to have a MP versus with friends thru internet, would've been much easier to play together. Not a big deal for missing the feature though.

If you're unsure if you're interested enough, you can try the tables for a limited time and see for yourself. I personally haven't bought/gotten every single tables, but I'm quite sure the more tables I have, the merrier it will be.

reviewText:
This tries to be a realistic pinbal experience, or as close as possible, and succeeds IMO.
Unfortunately, a realistic pinball experience doesn't necessarily make for a good videogame. I've written a long list of things I that would change to make this a beter video game.

That being said:
Everything about it feels good, like a pinball machine is supposed to. The physics in the game feel like you'd expect. The free table is very well designed, fun to play, and could give hours of fun on its own. A really good business decision they made is that you can try out any DLC table for a couple minutes as many times as you want. I've tried out many tables a few times to see if it was fun to me, which of course led to me buying some tables I'm really enjoying. The tables are reasonably priced as well, for a few dollars each (what a couple games on a real machine would cost) you can play as long and as many times as you want.

I'm not sure what more I can say other than try out the free table.

EDIT: Changed my review to negative, though it's best videogame pinball experienve I've had, due to devolper and moderator actions/attutude toward players.

The devs literally never check the forums, interact with, or take input from any player ever.
Zen reset the leaderboards and all of the (limited number who knew before it happened) players had much to say in suggestions to lessen the impact of the reset, but Zen listened to NONE of it. They just went ahead with the short-sighted, insulting, plans they made from their Fortress of Solitude. This caused many players to never return to the game. This includes legitimate top scorerers who helped out the community with support more than the moderator or devs ever have. The loss of this player and their help & advice was a big blow to the community.

reviewText:
Since Pinball Dreams (1992) I was playing back then, Pinball FX2 is probably the best pinball arcade I've been playing.
More than 40+ tables amongst which Star Wars hits offer a good variety of genres.
The leaderboards system is cool and the in-game system tells when you are about to beat your friend's score which enhances the lust for direct challenges.
On a few sidenotes.
There is also a tournament mode but I haven't seen any recently.
If you really look into some details, you might notice that the scoring  system isn't the same from one table to another meaning that reaching 10 million points can be extremely difficult compared to others where you reach that level in less than 5 minutes.
Besides those aspects, great set of tables, nice mechanics, cool music and sound effects and above all, replay value!

reviewText:
Is it nerdy of me that this is the first game I purchased on Steam (the Star Wars Pinball: Balance of the Force pack that is)? In truth, I bought this game not only because I adore pinball and Star Wars but because I couldn't add friends without buying something on my first day using Steam (oh how lonely that would be).

So lo and behold, I have a confession: yes, I am a nerd and playing Star Wars pinball to me is like nerd heaven! To tell you how much I love Star Wars, I used an exacto knife to make snowflakes in the shape of such awesome things like Death Stars and Boba Fett heads.

The Star Wars pack from Pinball FX2 boasts amazing graphics, fun and rapid gameplay, exciting movie scenes and special battles that you'll feel like you're truly in the Star Wars-verse. If you want to satiate your inner Star Wars fan and you love pinball (and have always wanted to go to that pinball Hall of Fame Museum in Vegas), then this is a must-play!

reviewText: This is the best pinball game I've played on the PC so far. Pinball FX2 offers a large variety of tables with plenty of action and lots of cool visual effects. All of the tables have lots of ramps and rails to shoot. I would say some of the tables are even overly busy which makes it difficult sometimes to see where you have to shoot the ball to complete objectives. The different camera angles help, but I don't like the close up camera angles because it reduces the overall field of view. The one major dislike for me is the lack of table friction. The ball skates around like it's on ice moving at blazing speeds and removes the genuine feel of a real pinball machine. The Epic Quest table is my favorite providing some engaging monster slaying with a few RPG elements--a really great game complete with good music and voice.

reviewText: This game is fun and easy to play, but very difficult to master. Each table is beautiful and stays true to its individual theme, while staying challenging and offering endless replay value. The tables are relatively inexpensive, but are a steal when they go on sale. I will say this, I have never played a game that makes me more frustrated than this one, however, I am addicted to this game and find myself constantly trying to beat my steam friends scores!

reviewText:
Got my first tables for this game in a Humble Bundle. I honestly wouldn't have bought 'em without that opportunity... and boy would I have missed something. If you happen to feel nostalgic about those times when there was a pinball table in every pub and you would throw coins at it in hope to beat your friends' scores, this game is a must have.

The only con point I can find about this game is the fact that it is all DLC. But hey, you got a free table (which is lots of fun) with the base game and you can try each other one for a short time so that you don't buy blind.

All in all, the game's replayability, the variety of tables and it's party game potential (thanks to local MP) make it a really good buy, which you probably won't regret. And if you still feel doubtful, just get the base game and play the free table for a while. There's no risk in trying... apart from the risk of getting addicted ;)

reviewText:
Well I really like this game.. what else can I say! Everything is pretty simple to follow and you do have a few options you can do with the settings although a couple of the controller ones might need a bit of work. Of course you can change the keys if you use a keyboard and there is a number of display and audio options. The restriction there is that the game is full screen - no windowed mode. It does have an orientation setting so you can even flip the game to portrait (90deg)- I was even stupid enough to try this and play it, now that was weird, but fun! I even toyed with trying to flip my monitor on my desk to match. Sheesh I mist be pitiful ;-)

The game itself is great, everything any pinball lover would want and it comes installed free of charge with 1 fully working pinball table, and it's no cheap table either - it's one of the better ones. Speaking of tables, well I haven't got them all yet and I guess thats the beauty of this system. You can try any of the available tables first in the game, it gives you a fairly brief period of time to play, just enough to get an idea of the table, then if you like it you can go buy it as DLC. Some tables are sold separately and there are also table packs (3 or 4 tables in the pack) which works out slightly cheaper.

My favourite table so far is Ms Splosion Man, it's kinda crazy - a bit like me I suspect. I have the 2nd highest score amongst my pinball friends on it - yet another thing about the game, you can add your friends or others with Pinball FX2 and see their scores in your game. That gives a bit of motivation to try and beat them. leaderboards, Wizard Scores and apparently tournaments - but I've not participated in one of those yet.

Most of the tables can be a bit daunting the first time you play, especially if you are like me and don't bother reading anything and just jump in and play. Thankfully however, there are guides for every table within the game, you can actually pause out and read what you are supposed to be doing during the game if you like. The guides are pretty good overall, they give you enough info on the various things you can do in a table without making you have to read forever. Fairly well set out as well.

Definitely worth the free download price and even more so worth spending money on for more tables to play. Get it!

reviewText: A treasure of the oldest school of arcade gaming with modern video game touches. The tables are deep, with a variety of skill levels and styles represented. reviewText:
Positives:
•	You get one table for free (which is actually a pretty good one) with unlimited play. You then also have the ability to try out all other tables before deciding if you want to buy them or not.
•	The menus are really easy to navigate
•	Big variety of tables, both in terms of theme and difficulty
•	Licensed Star Wars and Marvel tables!
•	Multiple camera views
•	Not very demanding in terms of hardware
•	Lots of content on the tables
•	Does things that are not doable on real-life pinball tables without overdoing them

Neutrals:
•	Would be nice to see some real-life tables implemented into the game.
•	Would be nice to be able to type in high-score initials with keyboard letters.

Negatives:
•	Some tables feels less polished than others

In the end:
This is a really fun pinball game with lots of good, original pinball tables.

reviewText:
I just recently started playing this game thanks to my boyfriend, and while I can't exactly say that I'm a fan of pinball, this game is actually a lot of fun. I've never played on a real pinball machine, so I can't compare this to the real thing. The game itself is free and comes with one table, but there are a lot of other ones available for purchase, and they seem to be making new ones every now and then.

Most of the tables look very nice and are very well-made. I was lucky enough to get ahold of quite a few tables through Humble Bundle at a great price, as well as one or two on sale on Steam, and at those prices it's worth it even if you might not be a hardcore pinball fan.

Some tables are more difficult to get high scores on than others, and every table has two achievements, so there's always a challenge waiting. My personal favourite is the Darth Vader table (both because I'm a fan of him, and because it's one of the few tables I'm decent at), but all the Star Wars tables are great in my opinion.

So, in short: Fun game. :)

reviewText:
picked this up late 2014 in a humble bundle with lots of Star Wars and lots of Marvel tables, plus several others. was a big fan of pinball when i was young (early to late 80's) and remembered liking the one included with Windows forever ago.

PROS

tables feel solid, very much realistic in their physics; can feel almost just as satisfying as any table i used to play IRL. i think they have done a good job balancing the fact that you can overcome physical limitations with keeping the play very much realistic in a physical sense, for the most part. the tables seem to cover most of the common pinball tropes that i recall; as well as having some devices of their own that can be seen to resonate through various parts of the collection.

also, in general, i think they've done a good job of keeping the challenge level to a similar level you would find on real pinball tables; a few of the tables feel a bit overly-inclined to take you to the drain down the side slots, or to throw the ball in the dead center of the flippers; but most have a decently long 'grace period' in which the ball is auto-relaunched if you end up draining quickly after launch.

also, the competitive part of the system is interesting; there are theoretically tournaments from time to time; but it's got good tracking of your ranking compared to your friends, with the stats being accessible easily, and a little trophy on the icon for each table for which you've got top score among your friends.

the menu UI is fairly intuitive and i have no real complaints in that department; it's not terribly inspired, but it's not a PITA either.

CONS

the flippers seem to only be available (i could have missed something somewhere) as left flipper"/"right flipper" control mapping
date: which can be a real pain on a few of the tables where this means you're constantly banging the ball into a flipper that should be on a separate button
recommended: or on an inverted control scheme. (e.g. an upper set of flippers mapped backwards.) mostly

reviewText: Absolutely stunning graphics, fabulous physics and challenging design makes the Pinball FX2 series a must-have for arcade pinball enthusiasts.  I have purchased all the tables with the exception of the new Dr. Strange, and played all a number of times.   I must say, the diversity of challenges and overall feel of the different tables is truly incredible.  Some flipper and ball action is lightning fast on newer tables, while others are true to their original old-school roots; those found in the Zen Classics Pack play slower and more subdued; you can almost feel the bulk of the flippers, with less flashy play and heavier movement.  Be it the 3D environments of the Star Wars or Marvel tables, the minimalism of V12, El Dorado or Mars, the flash of Ms. Splosion or the charm of Epic Quest and Earth Defense, there is something for everyone here.   IMHO, V12 and Tesla are the hardest to score points on; V12 has a rather brutal left lane gap that is an unholy drain of the worst order.  But for either a quick pick-up game or lengthy marathon, you can't go wrong with this re-imagining of an arcade staple.  You have your choice of 360 controller support (which is quite responsive) or keyboard bashing.  And the community score leaders and Pinball Wizard status allows you to not only challenge friends, but challenge yourself to reach the pinnacle of others playing a particular table.  Superb overview of achievements and table layouts compliment your quest, and you will find yourself unlocking new challenges at every turn. Highly recommended.

reviewText: The two biggest video pinball games on Steam are Pinball Arcade and this game. Both have similar revenue models (free with paid tables) and both offer dynamic viewpoints for optimal play. But while Pinball Arcade's legacy tables are nice, I would have to say Pinball FX2 is a superior product. It's not just the Marvel and Star Wars licensed tables (though they certainly help) but I feel Pinball FX2 definitely takes advantage of the fact that it is a video game and therefore its tables can do things that are incredibly difficult if not impossible on a real table (including mechanics and animated models) while still keeping realistic pinball physics. Pinball FX2 does not insult customers by offering professional" versions of tables. All tables feature operator menus and certain tables feature special balls (The Avengers table in fact makes it a gameplay mechanic). Besides Star Wars and Marvel
date: Pinball FX2 offers many tables that are a joy to play and very engaging. The Super League Football table in particular has become a table I am incredibly fond of. And lest not forget there is a free table in the form of Sorcerer’s Lair which is nothing to sneeze at. It's just as fun and of good quality as any of the paid tables.\n\nFor me
recommended: personally apart from the quality of the product
hoursPlayed: one of the biggest draws that encourages me to keep playing is the native integration with Steamworks so that all of your friends' high scores for any give table are automatically displayed in game. Thus it becomes a game in itself to see if you can best your friends' high scores.\n\nOverall this is a wonderful product if you enjoy pinball. I don't want to say its "better" than Pinball Arcade due to the different roles they fill
voteText: but it definitely has a much better pricing model. Must play."

reviewText:
Since the 90s, EPIC Pinball was the ultimate pinball video game choice. With the arrival of Pinball FX on XBOX 360 in 2007, it finally found its match, and 3 years later with Pinball FX 2, it got its successor, a new pinball king.
Zen Studios brought into the virtual pinball world, something that we have not seen before. Stellar ideas, ingenious presentation and perfect gameplay. Each table is a master piece of its own. So much to do on each of them and so much going on. Enriched with beautiful musical scores, great sound effects and animated 3D characters jumping around the tables.
If you take a few minutes away from the action, and hold the camera button while moving the mouse around, you can look at all the details and love that was put in every square inch of every table and also of the surronding area where the tables is standing. I love and play every single table that was made, except 1, Extreme, which is not present in Steam version anyway.
With so many tables present, with new ones coming all the time, you really cannot get bored, because when you make the whole circle through all the tables, the initals ones will feel so new and fresh again, you are ready for another tour, and another,.....

Whatever the system you're playing on, Zen Studios' pinball game is deffinitely the one you should not stay without.

reviewText:
This is a brilliant collection of 23  pinball tables  sold in six  separate packs (the Star Wars pack  has 3, the rest four tables each).  These are the  most beautiful tables I've ever played.  They almost feel like playing on a real table, the graphics are so good.

You can compare your high scores for each table with your friends, and  the accumulated high scores for each table   also place you on a separate   score table.

Ball physics is as good as it gets.  I do feel some of the tables lack the ability  to play skill shots,  they re more  about lucky than anything, but other tables compensate for  that.

If you like pinball games I recommend you don't wait till the sales and get them now.  I thought at first   the  full cost was prohibitive, but when you consider you are getting 23 tables,  it's actually a steal as each table works out at less than £1.40 each (approx $2)

reviewText: If you're looking for an authentic pinball feel - you won't find it here. Instead, you will get the essence of what makes pinball great in a super addictive package. There are so many well thought out mini games and goals on each table that it will boggle your mind. I suggest you disable the music as well as the pinball streak" effect before you play. It seems to help me focus and creates a more realistic feel. There are no authentic tables here. They are all original and each has a very unique theme.\n\nThey did a fantastic job of mixing elements that "could" be in a "real" table with stuff that would be physically impossible to create in real life. In my opinion - it's a perfect balance. Steam scores and acheivments are built in and will give you instant and real-time feedback of your skills as you improve. Seeing where you stand against your friends and everyone else in the world is all right there. It isn't buried behind some menu. I do not suggest using a keyboard to play if you can avoid it. Plug in a USB dual analog and remap the keys if you have that available to you. The graphics are crisp and full of color and effects. It's better (or on par with) than many Future Pinball tables i've played. It's a shame such high fidelity isn't available in the Pinball Arcade official release here on steam. More work may have been involved with that due to the tedious re-construction of actual pinball tables. Pinball Arcade goes for real tables and real physics but Pinball FX2 is loaded with creative & fun gameplay. It is obvious it's creators are PinHeads. It's a great balance of the real and the unreal!"

reviewText:
You love virtual Pinball? You'll love Pinball FX2! Like others have already stated, this is not simulation-like, but you get a hell of fun out of it anyway! There's a lotta tables to choose from, and they still keep coming! Try the free table Sorcerer's Lair, and if it's not too hard for you, throw some quarters in this machine!

P.S.
As someone who grew up with classic Star Wars, I strongly recommend the Packs Balance of the Force and Heroes Within (10 bucks each for 3 to 4 tables). Just play the demo of Han Solo and you see, hear and feel, what I mean... And by the way, you may skip the Noooooo"-scene on Darth Vader's table right from the start. Isn't that just 10/10 enough?"

reviewText: Their are only 2 pinball games that are worth ANY time, Pinball FX2 being one of them. When this first hit the xbox platform I finally found a reason to play xbox, well, other than the Forza series. Though, I probably even still spent more time in Pinball FX2. And now being on PC, I get to spend all my PC time (well, iMac time. Yes, it plays perfect on iMac too via CrossOver) again with my first true love, pinball. Of all the fantastic tables available, I think still to this day Secrets of the Deep in the FX2 core pack is still a huge favorite of mine. The crazy multi-ball on this table is just like awesome, and the music also helps take you from the real world and into pinball world. Yes, their really is a pinball world, though if you do EVER make it their, you will NEVER want to leave :)…  Each table has loads of variety and will keep you entertained for many many hours. If you even think you could love pinball, of even if you don’t, you owe it to yourself to try this. The FREE table it does come with, Sorcerer’s Lair was just one of the ones I purchased on xbox due to the fact its also a really good table. If I had to pick 1 issue with Pinball FX2, other than not being a native mac port, it would have to be I was really disappointed to not see the weekly leaderboard scores. But hey, it just means more hours to get the really big score to hit the top ten all-time leaderboards after all. Sorry, have to leave now to go find an opening to pinball world.. See you their……. If you make it...

reviewText:
SPOILER ALERT

pinball effects two is a game about the sport of pinball. That ball is so round and shiny. No other game of this decade has as round a ball. Fifa - NOPE Rugby game : NOPE Don Bradman Cricket 2014: HELL NO Peggle: Maybe Miniclip 8 Ball Pool: JEEZ NO

So yeah it's the roundest ball. There's loads of tables themed on different things. The Star Wars tables are based on that famous scene where Boba Fett tries to shoot a tiny ball with a laser. But that was in the bad trilogy of Star Wars films so you probably don't remember it.

There's a competent high score system and I don't understand where I'm getting all the points from. Only problem is I haven't played Pinball FX1 so I don't have any idea about the plot. But this is a good game and I'd start here for pinball fun on the computer gaming system.

reviewText: I totally recommend this game to you.\n\nIt reminds me of my golden amiga days spending my youth playing Pinball Dreams"
recommended:
"Slamtilt" and the like.

The only thing that is a little bad about this game is that there is no scrolling when played in horizontal screen orientation BUT you can switch it to a 90 degree rotated screen display so the whole table is displayed on your screen at once what I find a very neat feature after all. Of course you have to rotate your display too to play it properly in this scenario ... ;)

What annoys me a little is that the position of the flipper table's LCDs can't be fixed to the full width bottom or top of the screen like in good old amiga pinball games. Having this feature built in it would make it to the best modern pinball game known to me today (I still count "Slamtilt" under modern I must assume here ... ;).

Go buy it now! Presumably when it's on discount !!!

At the moment I'm writing this review you will get one table for free what makes it a really good offer even more than it is normally."

reviewText:
( TL;DR Just play the free table and stick with it or buy one or two more if you like their trials enough ^_^ )

FULL FEATURED FREE TABLE included with the core download so I just have to recommend everyone to try this out. It is one of the best of Pinball FX2 so that is definitely much more than just a demo. (Played it for 3 hours so far.) Also all other tables have time limited trials so it's pretty fun to try them out too.

Pinball FX2 is arguably the best digital pinball game you'll ever play. Finally there's game competing what Pro-Pinball gave a near perfect example in the late 90's. None of these tables are bad but with current selection of themes (what Steam version currently supports) are still 52% Marvel Comics. 14 tables with other themes are still unreleased on this platform but I bet they are coming eventually.

It's also fair to mention that each table stays in development from 6-9 months which definitely justifies that $3€ price tag but you don't really need more than the free one and maybe an additional table to start with. (This version finally supports vertical view for those weirdos who actually own a tiltable screen for some reason =P)

reviewText:
Pinball FX 2 or also named Zen Pinball, is a pinball game with many many pinball tables available, today at Steam not all tables are available yet but more tables will be released soon.

The gameplay of this game is unique, each table has been created wich so much detail and attention that it will take weeks to fully understand the table and how it works.
If you love pinball this is really a no brainer.
All tables have of course their unique themes like Starwars, Wolverine, Blade etc.

I really enjoy Zen Pinball and even though some things cant happen in real life pinball this stays a video game and really presents a great title.
Zen Pinball also has many other features except the singleplayer, you have your local score but also you compare your score with friends, worldwide, tournaments and many more.

This game is great and even unlocks the Pinball Wizard in those who never played Pinball.
Try out the free core game which is a demo!

reviewText:
One thing about the game is that it feels more organic.  In most pinball games, the game feels like it in entirely on rails, not just the visible ones placed on the table.  Once you learned how these rails work, earning large scores becomes an easy task.

That rail feeling is not a problem in this game.  The way that the ball moves, it feels more organic.  While where the ball is when you use the flippers is important, ball speed and bounciness are also a factor.  This makes that a shot that worked the first time will not necessarily work again the next time.  Having the ball move as it does in real life, it means that ball control is much more important in order to succeed.

The biggest draw about the game is seeing everything moving around on the boards.  Most modern pinball games have things that move around as things happen.  However, these movements are always simple that you can see even before the game start.  Once you trigger that movement, seeing it happen again is interesting only if it builds your score.

What makes the game unique among most pinball games is that game table feels alive.  As you trigger certain targets, things will happen that would never happen in a normal pinball game.  In Earth Defense, a giant robot is trying to attack you.  If its lasers connect, it will cause your ball to change direction.  In The Empire Strikes Back, Darth Vader will use his force powers to block and even destroy your ball if you get close to him.  Even in Infinity Gauntlet, Thanos will alter the gameplay by swapping the controls and even turning the table upside down.  With all the special movements that can happen, it makes it worth it to experience the special moments of each table.

Adding to the uniqueness are the games within the games.  Most pinball games will try to add more by simply using the scoreboard in order to play a bad video minigame.  Working with the video game format, these tables hold more than any physical table can hold.  In Moon Knight, he will use the ball as ammo to fire as hiding villains.  Tesla's table has a smaller table where you try to enter a goal using electro flippers.  In Paranormal, the ball can enter a higher second table in the attic in order to search for ghosts.  In what has to be the collection's highlight, in Star Wars: Starfighter Assault, you will go outside the table completely to shoot TIE fighter in what looks like the old-school game Galaga.  Knowing that there is more in store, spending additional time to explore them completely is a necessity.

The one sticking point with the game is the price.  They give everybody one table, Sorcerer’s Lair, as a free table.  For all the rest, you have to pay for them separately.  With individual tables costing three dollars and a pack costing 10, it can get expensive to buy the full game.  If you want the full package, it is necessary to pay over 100 dollars.  At that price, the best way to get it all is to try to get them through a bundle.  Without a bundle, you need to make sure you try each table before buying.

reviewText: I tried this initially as a curiosity, and now own all tables, and buy any new ones as they come out. This from a guy who's Father bought a Pinball Machine back in the day, had it at home. It truly brings Pinball into the computer age in stunningly impressive fashion, takes it to the next level and beyond. There isn't just scoring opportunity, there are layers, and many of them, and throught time you find the secrets to higher scoring, you can compete with friends or with the world, there's even Guides for the specific games, and beyond that it enhances fans of Marvel Comics, or Star Wars, and the latest one (as of this writing) with Soccer is an absolute blast, and I know nothing about soccer. Pinball FX2 is a gift that keeps on giving. Their most major competition, 'Pinball Arcade' is also good, and as they bring old school machines into your Steam, Pinball FX2 is the new school, and even ahead of its time. You simply can't go wrong with either, but this one dazzles...and dazzles layer by layer of accomplishments, scoring, competion, graphics and the one word to describe it all...FUN. Absolutely worth it.

reviewText:
Great fun pinball game for those who what a distraction or just unwind.  The physics aren't the most realistic but it's not supposed to be.  It's suppose to be fun and fast like any good arcade game.  They're a ton of tables to download all of which are fun in their own right (I'm partial to Infinity Gauntlet as well as Excalibur) and more coming along the way.

I'm hopping for more creative original tables, even though the license tables are fun I love the unique events in tables such as Epic Quest and Bio Lab.

This game is what made join steam for the first time so I can have all the tables (missing Dr. Strange) in my arcade cabinet.  Since then I have been buying up more steam games for my arcade cab that I made a second account and bought all of the tables again so I can I have a dedicated Hyper Pin machine when I get around to building it.

Game is really fun and always a blast at parties where everyone plays hot seat.  Got my money's worth ten time fold.

Worth every penny.

reviewText:
It's been a long time since I've seen a really good pinball video game.  Pinball FX2 pushes all the right buttons, bringing me back to when I used to play Epic Pinball on my 486 machine 20 years ago.  It fully supports both keyboard and gamepad control and both work very well.  My only gripe with controls is that manual control over the plunger is very difficult to use and only seems to utilize less than half of a thumbstick's range.

The main strength of this game is the table design.  Since all the tables are original, they aren't constrained by the laws of physics or physical design limitations like real tables are.  It allows the tables to all have their own unique feel and utilize game mechanics that are only possible here.  Unfortunately this brings with it some wonky ball physics in some places, mostly from balls rolling back down ramps though I believe this was done on purpose to avoid straight gutter balls.

The game utilizes global and friend leaderboards as well as having 2 achievements per table to add to replayability.  It's great fun beating your friends' scores and hunting down the achievements, some of which are extremely difficult.

On the downside, some of the tables have some minor performance problems such as stuttering when transitioning between the main table and a sub-table for a minigame.  Some people also experience input lag though I believe it is pretty rare.  Overall, the graphics are fantastic and it runs very smoothly so it's easy to ignore the sporadic problems.  A bigger issue for me is that the character banter on some of the tables (especially the licensed ones) can get quite tiring.  There does not seem to be any way to disable it without turning off the sound completely.

Some people may also be put off by having to buy tables separately.  They come in packs of 3-4 for $10 or single tables for $3 which seems pretty reasonable to me.  On sale, it's a bargain.  In addition, you can demo any table for a couple minutes before you buy to see if you like it before spending any money.  The game also has one free table that everyone can enjoy.

If you like pinball, this is the game for you.

reviewText: All round excellent pinball game, good physics engine and a nice variety of tables. Graphically very slick also. Highly recommended tables would include 'Plants vs Zombies', 'Ms Splosion man' (don't let the pink put ya off), and 'Quest for epic loot' (hope I got the name of that one right). The free table 'Sorcerer's lair' also has a high degree of replayability and a nice little 'mini game / sub table' section to add to the fun. Personally I play with a game pad but I see no reason why this would be any less fun playing with keys.

reviewText:
Pinball Hero

I adore Pinball titles and for a good few years now, I have been playing Pinball FX2 heavily on the Xbox360. Now its here on the PC and its just as good. The tables are almost all incredibly fun to play, each holding many different modes, specials and each one giving off an exciting vibe that first attracts you to the table, then makes you want to keep on playing.

Okay, its not the most realistic of pinball titles, lets be very clear. However what it does do is keep everything moving brilliantly with bonuses, game-modes, specials and secrets being thrown at you all over the place as you play. Then theres coming across the more unique tables, Avengers with its 'Character' selecting, Epic Quest with its RPG mechanics that carry over on each playthrough and Paranormal with the strange and tough as nails magnet boards.

Oh and did I also mention theres a 'Free' table called 'Sorcerers Lair' which happens to be amazing and full of the same secrets, game-modes and hidden bonus mini tables the others have? Well now I have. Unless you happen to hate everything pinball, there is NO reason not to pick this up and give it a shot. Heck, maybe even several.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I'm old enough to have played pinball as a kid. Over the years, I've watched games strive toward realistic physics. Most couldn't pull it off, but this game surely does.\n\nThis game retains the feel of classic machines, while adding lots of gameplay features that you couldn't do except with a computer. Pinball FX2 manages to be a perfect 15 minute time waster for anyone who used to mash flippers.

reviewText: OK, the game is great. The best pinball since ages. Tables are breathtaking and you can also play a bit with physics in options menu. It's highly playable. reviewText: As a child of the 90's growing up playing the pre-installed pinball game on Windows 95 (Space Cadet Pinball I believe) this genre of game holds a special place in my heart. I'm a huge pinball fan and pinball FX2 is a faithful and fantastic reincarnation of those childhood pinball memories. The option for arcade-style 4 person local play is great and the controls feel responsive and genuine playing on a 360 pad.\nGraphically this game is gorgeous although at max settings I have seen some frame stuttering on certain tables even with my Sandy Bridge i7 and GTX 680. I can see this being an issue when running the game on a low end PC since such precise reflexes are needed to master a table and reach those wizard high scores.\nThe only other mild complaint I have is not actually my own; I enjoy playing local games with my parents and while I have no trouble with video games, there are a handful of tables that are bafflingly complicated and opaque, the ball sometimes seems to be underneath" a piece of the scenery for 75-80% of the time that it is in play and it can ruin the fun. That being said
date: the problem is easily avoiding by not buying a table that you find hard to understand.\n\nIt's free (for one table)
hoursPlayed: and faithful to the pinball day's of old. Absolutely recommend to other 90's pinball fans!"

reviewText:
( TL;DR Just play the free table and stick with it or buy one or two more if you like their trials enough ^_^ )

FULL FEATURED FREE TABLE included with the core download so I just have to recommend everyone to try this out. It is one of the best of Pinball FX2 so that is definitely much more than just a demo. (Played it for 3 hours so far.) Also all other tables have time limited trials so it's pretty fun to try them out too.

Pinball FX2 is arguably the best digital pinball game you'll ever play. Finally there's game competing what Pro-Pinball gave a near perfect example in the late 90's. None of these tables are bad but with current selection of themes (what Steam version currently supports) are still 52% Marvel Comics. 14 tables with other themes are still unreleased on this platform but I bet they are coming eventually.

It's also fair to mention that each table stays in development from 6-9 months which definitely justifies that $3€ price tag but you don't really need more than the free one and maybe an additional table to start with. (This version finally supports vertical view for those weirdos who actually own a tiltable screen for some reason =P)

reviewText:
Pinball FX2 brings back the fun you had years ago playing the Windows-bundled Pinball games, or even playing pinball at arcades. The tables look fantastic, have many unique layouts, and include great combos and multipliers to unlock.

My only complaint is that despite having licenses for Marvel and Star Wars-related films, the voice characterization is garbage. None of the sound clips or voice acting is from the original licensed film that the table is related to, and is usually done by a vaguely-similar sounding voice actor. The voice clips are repetitive and will drive you insane quite quickly.

Recommended because yes, it is an insanely fun pinball game, but the voice acting will get on your nerves.

reviewText: Pinball FX2 is an involved, high-level game that requires your complete and undivided focus. It does not take much to play on a casual level, but for the driven and determined it is only the tip of the iceberg. In order to prove your worth in the FX2 leagues, you must provide every single ounce of your skill, awareness, flipper precision, and table bumping mastery to even begin on the lower levels of the ladder system. From there is a grueling journey upwards to being the very best at pinball. Perhaps, if you are enough of a video game master, you will able to top the high score of the Pinball Wizard for the ultimate in Pinball FX2 prestige. Pinball FX2, it's okay.

reviewText:
Graphics/Design - 8.0
Sound - 7.5
Gameplay - 9.5
Value - 9.5

Single Player Playtime - N/A

Overall 8.7

Here's a game I've spent a lot of time with.  The graphics are what you'd expect from a game where you only see a pinball table most of the time and the graphical options are minimal.  However, the great detail put into the tables and into the various minigames are where the game really makes it's mark in quality.  With all the crazy elements the average map has going on while you're playing, this obviously isn't a game trying to replicate an authentic pinball experience and Zen Studios uses this to their full advantage.  On Star Wars tables you might have X-Wings and Tie Fighters shooting at each other or anti-aircraft guns shooting at them.  You might see Darth Vader and Luke Skywalker fighting or Boba Fett in action.  Whether it's Star Wars, Marvel characters or any of the other tables, the table design, mini games and action on the sides have all been crafted to fit in with the reality of each tables fictional (or in some cases real life) universe.

There's nearly 50 maps out currently and you will find a dud here and there if you played every map but the number of high quality fun maps available is awesome.  The sound is decent, nothing particulary stands out there.  Considering how long you can last on some of the maps, it's the perfect game to listen to your own music while you play.  Some of the maps can feel cheap at times.  When you hit a seemingly good shot then it goes in one of the side gutters without giving you a chance to stop it, it can feel cheap.  You always want to feel like the reason you lost is because of a mistake you made, not because the table is designed to be very unforgiving to shots at certain angles.  The value someone can get out of this game is endless really.  There's enough maps out there to last hundreds of hours and hundreds more hours spent to truly master them all.  It's a great game with maps and patches that are still being put out for it.  Highly Recommended.

reviewText: Pinball FX2 is a blast for anyone old enough to remember these machines.  The physics engine does a good job of recreating the experience of a real game, and the table designs are interesting and innovative.  The base game includes one table to try, and Epic Quest is a great cheap addition for pinball newbies due to its low difficulty level.\n\nEarplugs, eyeshades, and cork not included.

reviewText: Absolutely fantastic video pinball. I was originally put off by the little animated 3D characters and ♥♥♥♥, but they don't change the fact that these are uniformly good pinball tables with pretty excellent ball physics. On top of that, they leverage the fact that it's a videogame by including some fantastical ♥♥♥♥ (Super mag-saves, little 3D dudes being pop-up targets, some really wacky things like flipping the table or really advanced mini-playing fields).\n\nI say a lot of dumb things in my recommendations but this one is completely honest. Good pinball.

reviewText:
Pinball FX2 is one of the most consistent PC Pinball platforms I've played. The tables are generally pretty good, and have a high level of polish. They do range in complexity and fun so make sure you read individual table reviews before purchasing them. I've never been dissatisfied with a table outright, but I can vouch for the following tables as being super fun:

Star Wars Episode V, Clone Wars, and Boba Fett
Epic Quest
Sorcerer's Lair
Marvel Moon Knight
Marvel Infinity Gauntlet

reviewText: Their are only 2 pinball games that are worth ANY time, Pinball FX2 being one of them. When this first hit the xbox platform I finally found a reason to play xbox, well, other than the Forza series. Though, I probably even still spent more time in Pinball FX2. And now being on PC, I get to spend all my PC time (well, iMac time. Yes, it plays perfect on iMac too via CrossOver) again with my first true love, pinball. Of all the fantastic tables available, I think still to this day Secrets of the Deep in the FX2 core pack is still a huge favorite of mine. The crazy multi-ball on this table is just like awesome, and the music also helps take you from the real world and into pinball world. Yes, their really is a pinball world, though if you do EVER make it their, you will NEVER want to leave :)…  Each table has loads of variety and will keep you entertained for many many hours. If you even think you could love pinball, of even if you don’t, you owe it to yourself to try this. The FREE table it does come with, Sorcerer’s Lair was just one of the ones I purchased on xbox due to the fact its also a really good table. If I had to pick 1 issue with Pinball FX2, other than not being a native mac port, it would have to be I was really disappointed to not see the weekly leaderboard scores. But hey, it just means more hours to get the really big score to hit the top ten all-time leaderboards after all. Sorry, have to leave now to go find an opening to pinball world.. See you their……. If you make it...

reviewText:
SPOILER ALERT

pinball effects two is a game about the sport of pinball. That ball is so round and shiny. No other game of this decade has as round a ball. Fifa - NOPE Rugby game : NOPE Don Bradman Cricket 2014: HELL NO Peggle: Maybe Miniclip 8 Ball Pool: JEEZ NO

So yeah it's the roundest ball. There's loads of tables themed on different things. The Star Wars tables are based on that famous scene where Boba Fett tries to shoot a tiny ball with a laser. But that was in the bad trilogy of Star Wars films so you probably don't remember it.

There's a competent high score system and I don't understand where I'm getting all the points from. Only problem is I haven't played Pinball FX1 so I don't have any idea about the plot. But this is a good game and I'd start here for pinball fun on the computer gaming system.
