reviewText: I totally recommend this game to you.\n\nIt reminds me of my golden amiga days spending my youth playing Pinball Dreams"
recommended:
"Slamtilt" and the like.

The only thing that is a little bad about this game is that there is no scrolling when played in horizontal screen orientation BUT you can switch it to a 90 degree rotated screen display so the whole table is displayed on your screen at once what I find a very neat feature after all. Of course you have to rotate your display too to play it properly in this scenario ... ;)

What annoys me a little is that the position of the flipper table's LCDs can't be fixed to the full width bottom or top of the screen like in good old amiga pinball games. Having this feature built in it would make it to the best modern pinball game known to me today (I still count "Slamtilt" under modern I must assume here ... ;).

Go buy it now! Presumably when it's on discount !!!

At the moment I'm writing this review you will get one table for free what makes it a really good offer even more than it is normally."

reviewText:
Finally! Not since Pinball Dreams/Fantasies have I played a pinball game this polished and this enjoyable. The key that makes this stand out, in my view, is the viewing angle & dynamic camera work along with the precise 'feeling of control' you can achieve with the ball. Most pinball games just don't get it right!

It doesn't have simulator accuracy but it is so fun! This does have an advantage as there are unique things on many tables you simply cannot do with a conventional 'real' pinball table design.

Tables all come alive with beautiful sound, animations & mini-games; the Star Wars tables have to be my favs!  Price of the tables is a little high when you add them all up, but you do get quality and all have great replayablity. Achievements are hard to get!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=147108739 { No Commentary - Straight Gameplay! }

Here is some straight gameplay footage to give you a longer look at the Empire Strikes Back table.

Addictive & Fun .. see if you can ace the high-scores! :)


If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

reviewText:
this game is ridiculously good....
ive NEVER come across a pinball video game that feels as close to playing a realt table as this does....the graphics, the sounds, and most of all the physics....the ball responds exactly how you would expect a real pinball to respond....
the only way it could come any closer is if there was a controller that was a box with two buttons on the sides for the flippers, a spring handle for launching the ball and motion support to smack it around for tilting....
also, the online leaderboards are cool....i have a lot of fun trying to beat peoples scores...
it also has a free table you can play all you want...so if youre curious even in the least about this game, download it and try the free table...i guarantee you that if you ever liked playing pinball machines at any point in your life, that youll be dishing out some cash for more tables....

10/10 for sure...

reviewText:
Pinball FX2 is a very polished product. The tables are diverse and well thought out, and common shots and ramps rarely drain directly unless you've put some weird spin on the ball.

In terms of bugs, the game is solid, but for me required a couple of system tweaks to make it playable due to what was otherwise pronounced input lag (disable v-sync and drop the maximum pre-rendered frames" setting to 1 in your video drivers). Check out the pinned thread in the Steam forums for more details.

Additionally
recommended: the Spiderman table is completely unplayable as a ball goes missing half way through a game and never reappears.\n\nNeither of the above problems was resolved when I recently refreshed my system with a new install of Windows 8 64
hoursPlayed: upgraded from Windows 7 64.\n\nA huge amount of work has gone into table designs
voteText: every table puts its own unique spin on things and all are originals. This means that they are also a little more forgiving than many real world tables as they don't have to factor in eating your money.\n\nAll tables reward skill
helpfulPercent: and generally offer a good variety of modes
votesHelpful: multiballs and combos to keep things interesting.\n\nThe ball physics are excellent
votesTotal: although ball speeds are perhaps a little bit faster than real world tables (noticeably faster on some tables
votesFunny: less so on others). Regardless
commentsCount: if you are already a fan of real-world pinball you won't have any trouble picking things up where you left off.\n\nEven though I've been a die-hard pinball fan for many years
column16: I've tended to shy away from electronic versions as they've not given me the same satisfying real world sense of interactivity
column17: from the slap of the flipper buttons to nudging the table.\n\nPinball FX2 doesn't solve this lack of physical interactivity
column18: in that controls are simply left and right space bars for the flippers and the control keys and space bar to nudge the table.\n\nIn my case
column20: I've recently acquired a new mechanical keyboard
column21: and if you're like me and need a bit more physical feedback to recreate the experience you're used to I can highly recommend the investment. My mechanical keys now provide exactly the right tactile slap from hitting the flippers.\n\nI also find that
column23: most tables are generous in awarding kickbacks
column24: and therefore my main reason for nudging is rarely necessary (and if you're not a decent player
column25: why would you even try?).\n\nThe sound is quite effective at ball-clack noises
column26: bumpers and the like.\n\nMy biggest gripe with the game is that some tables get carried away with the video-game potential through such things as glowing balls
column27: sped-up balls in certain game modes
column28: and full video-game style mini games.\n\nIf you are someone
column30: who prefers a more 'pure' pinball experience
column31: you will find that these tables can get irritating very quickly. Thankfully
column32: there is enough variety (if you can afford it) to largely stay away from the more painful examples. I've also turned off ball glow trails in options as I was finding the ball glow was sometimes interfering with my ability to read the ball.\n\nAs you will observe with a quick overview of the available DLC
column33: Zen Studios have taken full advantage of its Star Wars and Marvel licenses. In my view this is a shame as the non-licensed tables feel far more creative
column34: original and varied than those heavily reliant on movie imagery and sound-bites.\n\nOverall
column36: I've had a lot of fun with Pinball FX2 and can enthusiastically recommend it."

reviewText:
Usually, if a game prominently features balls, my review is going to contain a lot of puerile humor.  I cannot promise you I will make it through this review without discussing smacking balls, handling balls, cradling balls, being swarmed by balls, having your balls sucked down the hole....  You get the idea.  I am apparently still ten years old and there's just no helping that sort of thing when a game is fundamentally about how well it treats your balls.

I want to try and start this review on a sober note, though.  I am deadly serious about pinball.  I love pinball.  And, let's be honest, you do too or you wouldn't be reading a review about simulated pinball.  In the realm of games pinball is like a sharpened stick compared to the large hard-on colliders that are video games today.  But I still remember playing this one wicked old machine about a million years ago in my friend's aunt's basement.  We played that ♥♥♥♥ all night long, stomping the old high score into the dirt.  It was an old cowboy themed table, with no story or complex goals to achieve.  It was just a silver ball, a couple paddles, some targets, bumpers, and a ramp.  Your only goal was to keep the ball in the air, letting it cause as much chaos as possible while the score rolled up.  That ball was so ♥♥♥♥in' heroic.  And I don't mean like kids with cancer or a flower growing up through a crack in the sidewalk.  This was like the guy from They Live!" on a completely hopeless mission that he's got to do anyway because he's a badass.

That got rambly.  But you know what?  I don't care!  I measure every pinball experience I have against that cowboy table and the other pinball games I've played.  Come on
date: you do it too with your own tables.  Pinball's a nostalgia thing.  That's just how it is.  So to review Pinball FX2
recommended: I've got ask myself: how does this compare to the cowboy table?  How 'bout all the other real and simulated tables I've played?\n\nThe answer
hoursPlayed: like the game's protagonist
voteText: is gray and all over the place.  What Pinball FX2 does well
helpfulPercent: it does really well.  What it does badly is just inexcusable.  (And I played most of the non-free tables outside of my Steam account so my play time is higher)\n\nWhat does it do well?  Well
votesHelpful: there are visually interesting tables
votesTotal: with goals that pantomime simple stories and give you huge bonuses if you manage to meet certain conditions.  They're very much like the pinball machines I remember from arcades in the 90s.  I very much appreciate that the aesthetic of the boards is kept artificial and mechanical like a real table
votesFunny: but they aren't bound to that rule.  There are some imaginative
commentsCount: organic models and they use lighting and particle effects as you'd expect from a modern game.  It doesn't ruin the pinball experience
column16: but justifies a pinball video game because you can do impossible things you could only dream of doing with your balls in real life!  And such variety!  Break out a new table
column17: load your balls in the shaft
column18: and enjoy shooting them all over such beloved characters as Spider-Man
column20: and King Arthur.\n\nThe music is fairly engaging and
column22: the sound effects are satisfyingly weighty.  The game makes a good effort putting the camera how you want it with several different perspectives
column23: from zoomed in on the ball
column24: to hovering above the entire table.  It's not perfect
column26: because it can't be.  Let's face it
column28: in real life when there are some perfectly formed spheres in front of you
column29: all your focus is on them even though you're keeping the periphs on everything else that's going on.  But while it's all flattened out on your monitor that's just not possible.  Still
column30: they did the best they could.  And
column31: as playing pinball is like making love
column32: they give you options to adjust the angle of the table and thus the speed of the ball.  Though
column34: doing so will disqualify you from the leaderboards.\n\nSo what does it do so badly?  Well
column35: a few things.  The physics feel a bit off.  Woah!  That is seriously bad!  That is the one thing you need to be correct for a pinball game.  Yeah
column36: but they're not  too  off.  I'll freely admit it might even be my imagination
column37: but I swear the ball doesn't always behave consistently when I trap and shoot it from the same part of the flipper.  The gravity feels about right
column38: but once in awhile you'd definitely hear me screaming "BS!" at the screen.  Granted
column39: I might do that with a real pinball machine and I might just suck from not having played enough pinball.  However
column40: despite having controller support for nice modern pads like the 360 controller that has those nice analog shoulder buttons
column41: you can only smack the paddle at full strength.  Now that might be great if you have children acting up
column42: but pinball requires a gentler touch: floating your ball from one flipper to the other
column43: releasing your balls as if gently kissed by an angel.  That's pinball

reviewText: The layouts are awesome, and the level of detail is impressive.  My gripe with this game is the momentary lag between hitting the shift keys and the game registering a bumper movement. reviewText:
Pinball FX2 pairs classic pinball gameplay with themes from Star Wars, Marvel and more.
Each table can be played for a limited period of time, so you are forced to buy tables to enjoy the whole gameplay.
The look of the tables is good. The different pinball tables have variations and many of them have some little animations and action scenes. Super hero characters like the Marvel tables look like their comic book counter parts. This can be good in some instances and bad in others. The voice acting is generally good.
The keyboard controls work well. The pinball action is adaptable in case you do not like the default set up.
If you are a fan of Pinball games and you have some spare time, you can give Pinball FX2 a chance, but without payment, there will not be fun for long.

Sounds 7/10
Graphics 7/10
Gameplay 8/10
Atmosphere 7/10

If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

reviewText:
EDIT:

I am changing my review to a positive one after numerous concerns regarding user privacy were addressed by ZEN and Steam-specific EULA was created (and being implemented as of Aug 2015), clarifying ZEN's policy on type of user data collected and/or shared with Microsoft.

That said, the game itself functions like a collection of pinball tables, thematically divided into anything from Star Wars to legend of Excalibur. Though all tables are vastly different in terms of level design, difficulty and feel, all tables feature outstanding music and/or voice acting, tight controls and outstanding visuals (though somewhat problematic camera view).

All in all, recommended to lovers of pinballs (both the physical and digital varieties).

reviewText:
Pinball FX2 has a great sense of direction.  It is taking the modern age of computer graphics and incorporating new and refreshing tables for pinball enthuisits that no longer have the arcades in their hometown anymore.  The sound effects resonate like the original pinball machines and the feel is pretty accurate.  It comes with 1 free table you can play endlessly and there are a ton of extra tables you can get as downloadable content.  I recommend picking up your table of choices when they are on sale as the price point otherwise seems a bit steep.

Here is my review of the product.
Have a great day gaming!

reviewText:
Who doesn't likes Pinball? Pinball is one of the oldest, simplest and greatest game ever.
It's simple, it's fun, it never gets boring.
There's some DLCs for people who want to play on table of something they like.

I'd wish it has at least one of The Lord of the Ring, Indiana Jones, The Matrix, Star Trek, Stargate, DC (especially Batman) and Spider man, perhaps one of Dragon Ball/Dragon Ball Z and Naruto?
Shouldn't be too hard to get the rights for The Lord of the Rings and Indiana Jones.

Anyway, great classic and great game.

9.5/10 for Pinball Itself.
9/10 for this game.

reviewText:
The Star Wars tables and Avengers Chronicles tables are the best in my opinion. Of the Star Wars tables, I enjoy the Return of the Jedi table in the Balance of the Force pack the most, but they are all fun. The Avengers table itself is a MUST play. I got the Avengers tables mostly for Infinity Gauntlet, but it is a strange table to play. On the plus side, it has the element of surprise much like the old school tables that sucked quarters in the 80s. You can DEMO all the tables, but there are so many now, you could miss out, so thought I would mention these as ones to check out for sure.

Some tables become much more playable when you change the default angles and things, but you can't count those scores.

I'd like to see something more done with the community on modding tables, or voting on what they'd like to see changed and competing on that community table" of the month or something."

reviewText: Pinball FX2 is the best pinball simulator that I have ever played. The variety of tables is fantastic and they aren't very expensive, especially if you buy them in packs. You feel like you're playing an actual story on many of the tables. I love the Star Wars and Marvel ones (the Fear Itself table is a true standout...a perfect package of challenge, depth, and a great soundtrack). You can toggle through several different views while playing, including the traditional overhead view in case the 3D views seem too awkward.\n\nDownload the free game and buy a pack or two during a sale. You won't regret it.

reviewText: Pinball FX2 is the best pinball simulator that I have ever played. The variety of tables is fantastic and they aren't very expensive, especially if you buy them in packs. You feel like you're playing an actual story on many of the tables. I love the Star Wars and Marvel ones (the Fear Itself table is a true standout...a perfect package of challenge, depth, and a great soundtrack). You can toggle through several different views while playing, including the traditional overhead view in case the 3D views seem too awkward.\n\nDownload the free game and buy a pack or two during a sale. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
TL;DC: Honestly I'm surprised how much fun this game is. WIth the varity of tables, amazing physics & graphics, and endless replay value, this is one of my top games.

My previous experience with this game is a LOT of hours on Xbox, but I just got this on steam so that I could play on my monitor that tilts sideways for a better pinball experience.

The key for me to getting a lot of enjoyment from each a table is to learn the rules, tricks and storyline (but don't try to do it all at once) - over time you'll learn to progress the table's story and / or help rack up your points. Eventually you'll master a table and by that point you'll already be addicted. A single 3-ball game can last quite a while once you've mastered a table.

If you just aren't into a particular table, move to another. The table demos do a poor job of giving you a feel for how a game will play out over time, but at least you get an idea of the design. I purchased most of my tables based on reviews. A great first board is Epic Quest. A lot of players also love Fear Itself as a good starter table. By starter I don't mean they are easy"
date: it's just these boards are loved by a lot of players. Picking a dud as your first table could ruin your experience.\n\nThe table designs are mesmerizing. The game play is much deeper than you might imagine. Every time I load up a new board
hoursPlayed: but I try to just focus on passages and taking it step-by-step. I never just read through the entire table guide. I'll learn part of it
voteText: master it
helpfulPercent: and then move on to learn something new. Unlocking a table's secrets on your own is half the fun
votesHelpful: and every single table is differnt.\n\nI'm truely amazed at the creativity behind each table layout. Some are hareder than others
votesTotal: some more rewarding
votesFunny: some more about story
commentsCount: some about scores
column16: and in the end
column17: everything comes down to just how you play a particular table."

reviewText: I keep coming back to this game over and over. It's compulsively satisfying, and offers new experiences with each board. It's unfortunate that each board or group of boards is a separate purchase. However, if you like the board after a demo, you can absolutely get your money's worth with each board.\n\nI've lamented the lack of pinball games in arcades, but this is absolutely satisfying pinball experience that is certainly cheaper in the long run than the quarter eating arcade machines.

reviewText:
A great pinball game with a single free table which is very fun and complex (lots of secrets, 2 achievements, various mini-games ...).

Xbox360 controller is highly recommended for convenient reasons :)

Additional tables can be bought as DLC for several bucks each. At the moment, I only bought 1 optional table (Walking dead)

However, the game has some significant cons:
- Locked tables can only be played several minutes (like a very SHORT demo)
- Getting all tables is very expensive (>> 50 bucks)
- Impossible to unlock a lot of achievements (table-dependant) without buying associated tables (only 2 achievements are linked to the free table)

### Conclusion:
The game is really good and addictive, but too expensive (quite surprising for a Micro-$-oft product ^^)

14/20

reviewText:
WARNING: You may experience input lag!  You can fix it, but you have to do so manually.  See: http://steamcommunity.com/app/226980/discussions/0/666827315349070543/

It's alright.  If you like pinball, maybe check it out.

Menu's are acceptable.  The pinball mechanics work and that's about all I'm asking for here.  It's acceptable and if you like pinball you'll probably be ok with this game.

I have not seen an already established table appear on this program yet, which has left me disappointed.  On the plus side, as this is a virtual program, the tables I've played on have mostly done things I've either never seen before or are not exactly feasible on a real life table, so that's a huge plus.

However, quantifying if this game is good/bad is difficult as that mostly depends on the tables.  There are both bad and good tables and, from what I've played so far (5 or 6 tables) the name brand ones (star wars and marvel ones) are not nearly as good as the weird original ones (Tesla is pretty cool).  If I recall you can demo the program/tables, so there's that.

Right now there are about 30ish tables available, so there's a lot of variety.  On the few I've played so far there hasn't been a lot of skilled play so much as flipper mashing, but that's also true for a lot of boards (I've only played one or two that were actually quite fantastic in real life).

Anyway, if you like pinball to an unhealthy degree this might be worth checking out, although there are also pinball emulators out there that have real tables on them, so you might consider that as well.  As a buy?  Not terrible, I guess, but I would investigate the dlc (tables) further before you make a purchase of one.  I was pretty disappointed with the Marvel ones.

reviewText: 6/10\n\nI’m a huge fan of pinball and while Pinball FX is a fun game, it’s not a good recreation of the actual table experience. The boards are interesting and fun to play but the actual mechanics are really bad. The physics on the balls are way too bouncy and unrealistic; it’s a much more fast paced than playing an actual table. I would recommend only to those who really love pinball and are looking for boards to play beyond the ones offered in Pinball Arcade (a much better game overall).

reviewText:
One of the best pinball games in history. Despite the fact that you need to buy tables separately, it's awesomely good. The physics are great, plus it doesn't try to be a fully realistic sim, so you get things like shooting blasters, balls changing physical properties, etc.

The only minus here is the low usefulness of table nudges. They don't influence the ball too much, and they have a very long cooldown, so it's very easy to tilt the table. (The best nudges IMHO were in Balls of Steel where one could play for a good while by using them and without using the flippers. :-) )

I highly recommend it, even if only for the free table.

reviewText:
I have far too often been disappointed with following comments I read ahead and follow. Same with my own prejudices which must fall to the wayside in the decision for or against. I have personal preferences in favor of Bruce Lee, Jet Li and Steven Seagal; the directorial work of Robert Rodriguez and Tsui Hark; but I find that following my own preconceived notions do not work when deciding on something new.

However, my friend recommended Pinball FX2, and I do like pinball games as a rule. I went ahead and took the free download and I must say the *free* Sorcerer's Lair table is pretty good; and being free, well ... if I was to be disappointed, I can't ask for much of a return. On this score I tried Pinball Arcade, and that one did indeed serve me great disappointment, even though it was free.

My interest in this version has grown and this morning I looked for and found the Fantastic Four table at a price I thought to be a bargain; and well, here is my review. I caution any gamer, movie-goer, book reader or - well - consumer - to make up their own mind, this is my own opinion - It's a great game!

I have personal preferences in favor of Bruce Lee, Jet Li and Steven Seagal; the directorial work of Robert Rodriguez and Tsui Hark; but I find that following my own preconceived notions do not work when deciding on something new.

However, my friend recommended Pinball FX2, and I do like pinball games as a rule. I went ahead and took the free download and I must say the *free* Sorcerer's Lair table is pretty good; and being free, well ... if I was to be disappointed, I can't ask for much of a return. On this score I tried Pinball Arcade, and that one did indeed serve me great disappointment, even though it was free.

My interest in this version has grown and this morning I looked for and found the Fantastic Four table at a price I thought to be a bargain; and well, here is my review. I caution any gamer, movie-goer, book reader or - well - consumer - to make up their own mind, this is my own opinion - It's a great game!

reviewText: Edit - The below review was meant to be a review of the Super Football League (Zen Team) table.\n\nThis was a table I spotted released a while back, and I was excited about it.  Sports is a common theme for actual pinball, and it is nice to Zen take a dip into that genre.  I jumped on the -50% price during the summer sale, and I am not disappointed.  For what is the price of 3 plays (at 0.50 ea),  You get a very original table that really puts you into the illusion that you are playing a game of football (soccer).  I like the fact that the table hinges on hitting mostly ramp shots instead of a lot of gimmicks, but it does a nice job of building up the pressure on you to score when the time is right.  You almost forget you are playing pinball but not in a bad way.  This is a great table, and it doesn't seem to matter which team you choose as they seem to be the same except for the colors and individual players named through the course of the game.

reviewText:
Simply put, one of the most immediately addicting games I have ever played; gorgeous and cleverly designed tables galore.

If you don't like pinball, you probably won't enjoy this title. It does innovate, but it doesn't change what it is at it's core.

+Endless replayable hi-score fun.
+Original tables from the dev's with rich themes and additions that wouldn't be possible on a real table.
+Graphics and sounds are what you would expect.
+Leaderboards and stats galore.

-From what I can tell, no real life tables. Those seem to be the focus of the other pinball game on steam, Pinball Arcade. Unfortunately, that game charges an insanely high amount for their table recreations - but that's exactly what they are, recreations of real tables, which is what Pinball FX2 lacks. My main gripe is that some tables made by Zen for Pinball FX are a little broken, whereas the tables in Pinball Arcade are based on real life tables which seem to be balanced better overall. The tables in Pinball FX2 are sold at a very fair price.

reviewText: Zen Studios pinball FX2 offers tons of tables at a reasonable price. You get to try every table so you can buy just the one's that you like. I also appreciate the different camera angles as I can always find one that I like. Effects are well done and I have yet to experience any glitches. The Number of choices is ridiculous. I personally would suggest the star wars pack, and zen pinball classics pack while I think that the paranormal table is too easy.\n\nMy biggest complaint with Pinball FX2 is the lack of cross-buy. Zen Studios has released the same tables on every device imaginable from OS X to Android, to PC, to the 3DS and to the Consoles, but if you buy a table on one platform you can't use it anywhere else. This is especially annoying as I use a macbook air and a windows desktop, but Pinball FX2 is only for windows. Zen Pinball 2 is the OS X name of this game.

reviewText:
Played for only 2 hours So I decided to give this game a review. Here are the Pros n Cons of this game
****Pros****
1) Graphics are really nice, it can run on high quality graphics on a low computer
2) Controls are easy, and even better if you have an Xbox 360 controller
3) The download is quick, maybe 30 min to an hour.
4) Tables are cheap and quick to get, there are collections you can unlock for dirt cheap prices.
****Cons****
1) You get ONE free table, kinda sucks In my opinion, but they're cheap as i mentioned above.
2) This is basically the same exact game as the Xbox has, just not with all the unlocked tables, if you want to spend $20 on a 360 game go ahead, otherwise get this game and buy only tables you want, for much cheaper prices.
that's what I got so far. I rate it 9/10. Because of how fun it is.

reviewText:
A great and realistic game, but where it really, really starts to be several times more enjoyable is if you're playing it on a widescreen monitor in portrait/vertical orientation (ie, same shape as a pinball table). If you've got it in mode 1, there's no sea-sickness as it swooshes around. Try it. Even better if you lie it down somewhere too! (see my avatar for what I've been playing it on)

My Favourite table is the Plants Vs Zombies one.

(Note: I got this game from Humble, and have been playing this in offline mode on a PC which is only ever connected to the internet if I'm downloading something, so the current time of 27 minutes isn't accurate. As of the time of writing, I've probably clocked up about 4-5 hours on it.)

reviewText: Fun!  nice game to play for short periods instead of being tied to the screeen for an hour at a time (or more).  Physics are good and you can 'feel' the tables when you play them. reviewText: A fairly good, arcadey pinball game. Definitely a game and not a simulator. I enjoyed it more when I turned off the cartooney ball trails. The only table I like at all (but I love it) is Epic Quest. I hate every other table I've tried and I think I own 20 of them. The other tables have unsatisfying gimmicks and very amateurish voices that drag the merely passable tables down further. If it wasn't for Epic Quest I'd never touch Pinball FX2 but it's a million laughs and a genuinely good game.

reviewText: This is a great pinball game that understands it's also a video game. It has a more arcadey feel then compared to Pinball Arcade, but there are also a lot of interesting things the game can do since it is a digital playfeled and not trying to recreated a existing physical one. One instance being on the Mars table where a new, holographic ramp can appear. It's really responsive, looks great, has some great tables (most of the Marvel and Star Wars ones). While the tables are priceier than Pinball Arcade, it's a different kind of expereience and I think it is worth the money.

reviewText: Pinball FX2 goes beyond what real world pinball tables could do, making extraordinarily deep and varied experiences. Tables vary a bit in quality, from very good to wonderful, and I've yet to find a table I didn't enjoy at least a little bit.  But be warned, tables do have to bought separately (or in some small bundles), so the upfront cost is not the final cost.  But as long as you're aware of that, this is the best computer pinball there is (Pinball Arcade is a close second, with its focus on real world table recreations, so if that's what you're looking for, go there instead).

Pinball FX2 is a FREE TO PLAY game, but you have to pay for the tables themselves. Pinball FX2 pairs classic pinball gameplay with themes from Star Wars, Marvel and more. Pick and choose the tables you like from a selection of dozens - there's something for everyone! Meticulously constructed in painstaking detail, each table is instantly approachable yet offers dozens of hours of replay value. You'll need all the practice you can get to defeat your friends' high scores and earn the title of Pinball King. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
I think it's about time to share a few words about this game with people that might be looking for a reason to give this a try.

Well I certainly hope that you know what pinball is. Even if you never came in contact with the real thing you probably played the old pinball on Windows XP or at least heard about it right? No? WELL WHAT THE HELL ARE YOU DOING HERE THAN? Real pinball works on a basic principle. You throw in a quarter and it usually gives you 3 balls to play with.
You are trying to not let the ball drain with your flippers while getting a score for anything you do. Once all your balls are lost, the game ends and you take place on the leaderboards. Sounds simple and it can be, depends how you look at it and what table are you playing.

Which brings us to this electronic pinball game. It's not going to ask you for quarters to play! In fact, it's like you have your own pinball machine at home where you just push start and you are given free balls to play with. But this thing is not going to cost you hundreds up to thousands of dollars and it's not going to take up a big space. This game will only take up space on your HDD and each table will cost you 2.99€ or your regional equivalent.
There's one free table for you to play with and every other table you can just try for free. The free table in question is Sorcerer's Lair and it's alot of fun! You'll find many hours of enjoyement on this free table alone and it will give you a good idea about how the game works and if it suits you.

The physics are very real, if it could be any closer to its real counterpart, it would be just scary. The speed might seem to be a bit too high but there are many realy tables that are even faster. This is still very fair but will make damn sure to test your fast hands out. Your ball can drain without you knowing what just happened, but that's the way it is. As you play more and more, you will eventually get better too.

If you are by a chance a fan of MARVEL or Star Wars, you are going to be happy as there are many tables in these themes. At the time of writing this there are 2 South Park tables, a Walking Dead table (based on the first game by telltale games), a plants vs. zombies table and many original design tables for you to choose from. Some are easy, some are hard, some are not worth getting as much as the others. But they are all quality products and you can really see that alot of hard work went into all of them. And as I said, you can try before you buy" so you won't have to blindly buy into things you might not like in the end.

The community is really friendly and if you find yourself playing pinball FX2 alot
date: you might want to go check out an amazing steam group by the name of "Pinball Family" and ask for an invite. We are competing there each week on a different table
recommended: players of all skills!\n\nAll in all: if you are looking for a quallity electronic pinball
hoursPlayed: don't look any further

reviewText:
You have to ask yourself one question.  How long can you keep Isaac Newton from laughing about your balls?

This.  This is my favorite game on Steam.  Pinball Arcade is just as good, but the currently impossible-to-manufacture tables that aren't trying to chew your quarters really lets your mind go to a zen state, and then a Logitech F310 or controller of choice becomes an extension of your consciousness.  Don't play for a high score, or for extra balls, the only one that matters is the last one on the table.  It's difficult to tell people what drives a person to play this game, but it's easy to recommend to everyone, if you are in the right mood to battle physics.

9,5/10 equal to Pinball Arcade.

Play for fun, and keep this bit of trivia in mind: it costs $2 to play one game of pinball in real life.  Play a table in this game 100 times over the course of a year or more?  The value doesn't even make sense unless you remember being in an arcade with these competing with Mortal Kombat and Street Fighter.  Here, you don't have anyone judging your technique, there's a guide for every table a Start button or Esc key away explaining every detail you could ask about how to destroy a table.  Video guides if you have a friend you really want to beat, but your opponent is really yourself -

Guardians of the Galaxy is a really energetic, fun table, and so is the South Park pack if you like the show.  The Walking Dead table is amazing if you've played the Telltale RPG series.

reviewText:
Edit: According to some other reviews on here, there is a new Terms of Service with some questionable new policies. My review is of the game itself and I have not played in several weeks so I was unaware of it. Check out some of the other reviews here or research a bit before downloading. I apologize for the outdated review.

I'm 23. Though nowhere near old enough to have memories of arcade pinball machines, I am old enough to have nostalgia over virtual pinball games!

Simple games are often the best in my opinion, and everyone knows how to play pinball. It is quite literally two buttons. Pinball is a concept any kid can understand. My free time after school often consisted of running home to play, of all things, Microsoft Windows Pinball. Looking back, it's amazing to me - a game that came free with our operating system had captured my attention for hours. On the go, I had 1999's Pokemon Pinball on my GameBoy Color. Now this one was more advanced - it had the Red table, and the Blue table (named after the Pokemon Red and Blue games), and they were different. I was amazed. I was addicted. I mentioned I like simplicity. To me, there is something to the objective of getting a high score. Challenging yourself, topping a friend's score, the way your heart starts beating fast as you realize you're edging in on a top score - these are some of the best feelings in gaming.

Pinball FX2 gets that. It understands the simplicity of the fun that comes from hitting a little silver ball around a table, trying to top that last score. It eggs you on. It notifies you when you're about to beat that score, or a friend's score.

It also understands my childish excitement when I saw Pokemon Pinball had two options for tables. It has dozens of tables, and I have yet to play one I didn't greatly enjoy. Zen has many original tables within the game, and there are some great licensed tables as well. You can find tables from the Marvel and Star Wars Universe. Some more series you will recognize are The Walking Dead, South Park, and Plants vs. Zombies. I will say Pinball FX2 is a bit heavy on the Marvel and Star Wars (so if you're not into those, there are a reduced number of tables you'll be interested in), but since you buy tables separately, you can just choose not to buy them. The quality and originality of every table has impressed me every time I try a new one, so even if you're not into the lore" (as I'm not crazy on the Marvel universe)
date: you may find the tables still well worth playing.\n\nHere is also a bit about the "pay structure" - the game is "free to play" technically. Everyone who downloads Pinball FX2 gets the Sorcerer's Lair table
recommended: which to be honest is a fantastic table you could entertain yourself on for hours. One of my favorites for sure. Anything else is sold separately
hoursPlayed: in "packs" (ie. the Star Wars and Marvel packs) or as individual tables. They are ALWAYS on sale during Steam sales so if you are eyeing a table but don't want to pay full price
voteText: I recommend just adding it to your wishlist and waiting!\n\nIf you love pinball games

reviewText:
So tell me of this mysterious game

Ahhh, Pinball, a superficially simple but subtly complex game.
A game where heroes are forged in the fires of force and geometry, a game where dreams are shattered by that evil temptress called gravity.
A game that separates the men from the boys, the women from the girls and the Wizards from them all!
Welcome to the intense, extreme and often emotional sport of Pinball!

I wish to be a wizard separated from boys and girls!

This isn’t a journey to be undertaken lightly my friend, but if you are sure, I will teach you!
Come with me as we traverse the pleasures and pitfalls of this wild and exhilarating sport.
Throughout the course of this review we’ll journey through the basics, the concepts, the joys and the jargon.

I’m going to give you all the information you’ll need to be a pro, as for becoming a wizard?
Well that’ll take hard work and dedication, but I have faith in you my prodigy.

Field of Dreams

As a potential paragon of pinball, you will first need to be aware of the forum of the faithful that is the arena for this glorious sport.
This arena or playing field takes the form of a table, but not just any table, this is a table with a slant, rising upward before you like the altar of aspiration it truly is.
As an aspiring Baron of the Balls, you will take your place at the base of this tilted table of temptation. You should strive to feel comfortable here; this is where dreams are made.

Balls of Steel

On to this table you can launch a steel ball, your avatar on this plateau of promise.
The tormenting tilt of the table will then conspire with gravity to defeat you as your ball succumbs to their merciless grip and begins to roll downwards towards impending doom.

Impending Doom?

That’s right. At the base of this alluring alter of ambition lies the abhorrent abyss of agony, the pit, the void, the gaping mouth where all balls are inevitably sucked.
Despite your skill level, this will eventually happen to you. It is the destiny of every ball to be sucked into the mouth eventually.
But fear not friend, you are not defenceless, you can fight back.

They Call Him Flipper

On this tilted board of dreams you also have some interactive devices the pros like to call “flippers”
At the press of a button you can utilise these “flippers” in an attempt to intercept the rolling steel ball and change its path, hopefully away from the previously mentioned hole which is waiting to consume your ball.

Nice Pins

If that isn’t enough excitement for you, the table also has strategically placed targets which we’ll call pins.
Although your primary objective should always be to avoid the devouring pit of doom at the base of the table, you also have the secondary goal of trying to hit the various pins with your mighty ball of steel.
So it’s a game of pins, balls and tables.
If you want to sound like a “real pro” you should refer to this pinned platform of perils as a “Pinball Table”

Pinball Wizard

But wait, there’s even more. The order in which you strike these “pins” can also be important.
If you strike the correct targets consecutively you may be awarded with additional points to help boost your score.
That’s right; the pinball table isn’t only there to confound you with its attempts to swallow your balls.
You can also quantify your prowess through the facility of a score.
This is where the true pinball wizards achieve their bragging rights.

If only there was some sort of training simulator

So, now you’re ready to master the mechanics of the fickle mistress that is pinball, but which game should you choose to hone your developing pinball powers?
Surprisingly, when looking for the simulated experience of this seductive sport, you’ll find that the market isn’t exactly flooded with titles.
Sure, there are a few options out there, but if you’re serious about your pinball wizardry then the “go to” game at the time of writing is Pinball FX2 and best of all the price of admission is free.

Free is Good

Most of us can afford “Free”, in fact it’s my favourite price point for a game.
So what do you get for an investment of zero? A pretty well designed pinball table with all the bells and whistles you’d expect from a digital version of the game, that’s what.
As well as the free table to cut your teeth on (which will likely give you many hours of game time on its own before you get bored), you also get the chance to enjoy a few minutes play time on many of the additional tables available to purchase in the game.

More Please

When you do decide to move on from the starting table, the choice is vast, from the generically themed tables of Rome and Tesla through to Star Wars and The Walking Dead, you’re sure to find a table to suit your mood.
The additional tables are reasonably priced, and although you’ll undoubtedly have your own favourites, they are all of a high standard, expertly designed and fun to play (and yes, I’ve played through most of them)

Let’s Get Physical

The physics in Pinball FX2  is spot on. The ball bounces around exactly as you’d expect it too, the motion is fluid, the flippers respond smoothly and no matter how frantic the action gets, everything rolls along nicely.

Master your Balls

Pinball FX2 is an outstanding title in the genre; it sounds good, it looks amazing and it plays better than the real thing.
There’s a score table out there waiting to put your name up in lights.
It is time for the student to become the master.

Go now, Show the world what you can do with your balls!



( To view the full review (and others) please take the time to visit http://www.review-well.com/  )

reviewText:
Pinball FX2 (known on some platfroms as Zen Pinball 2) a solid pinball game with tight controls and good physics. What helps to set this apart from other pinball simulators is that the game is not limited to things that are possible on real tables, such as character interaction or varying minigames, also the wide array of licensed tables (mostly from Mavel and Star Wars) might be a draw.

The biggest downside i've seen of this game so far is that the game is sold in pieces, which may or may not be a good thing depending on your tastes. There are various packs, single table purchases, and bundles to choose choose from that it might be overwhelming, but the game does allow for you to demo every table for a few moments. Also because this is how the game is set it, its constantly reminding you of the content you do not own.

There is also a ton of customization options from graphical settings to viewing angles that you can find the layout that works best for you. Sadly, this version of the game is missing its online multiplayer component, leaving the only form of competition you can have up to various leaderboards that can be in general or between your Steam friends.

Ultimately if you need one Pinball game, this one can do the job nicely between its feel and wide table variety, just dont be weary of the game being sold in pieces.

DISCLAIMER: There is apparently some nasty documentation with the wording in the End User License Agreement that could allow the game to be updated to serve as spyware on your PC. I have done some research before I ever downloaded the game and discovered the game itself (as of this review) does not do this at all. Zen Studio's also recieved a big enough backlash that they said they'd ammend the EULA some time ago but have yet to for reasons unknown. I am personally confident both developer Zen Studio's and publisher Microsoft Studio's would not be so foolish at this point in time to gather untold information outside of the game itself at this point.

If the presense of this info on the EULA still is making you uneasy or you do not wish to keep tabs on this situation, i'd remomend just waiting until the EULA is altered to either remove that portion entierly or to adjust it to clearly state they are only gathering background information in-game on your   usage and purchase habits(in the context of providing a better service or selection to its users).

reviewText:
Just simply the best video pinball game I have ever played. But what is even better are the DLC tables. The tables are original and well designed and just great fun to play. I am terrible at both real and video pinball, but it really doesn't matter, the games are just good fun.

I must have played over 30 real pinball tables at Play Expo Manchester 2015 and I didn't really enjoy playing a lot of them. The ball speed and flipper response just didn't feel smooth and natural, I can't explain why.  Or the tables seemed boring. Great art but no substance. Playing this game with the xbox controller feels great, very natural and responsive. And the tables designs are just really up there with the best of the real pinball tables. Fantastic art, lots of action and lots of depth if you are any good at pinball.

If you like pinball at all, or have always wanted to try pinball, then this is the only one to download.

reviewText:
PINBALL Hmmm....

I started and have loved playing pinball since before arcades and video games existed. A quarter bought you 5 balls and 2 of them, bought you 3 games. Pool Halls are where you found a few machines to slap the ears and knee the coin box of your favorite machine. Yes I am that old. That being said...

I have been extremely unimpressed with video recreations of pinball until now. Pinball FX2 hits the the target @ the bullseye. Zen has captured the heart of pinball in this version. The physics are spot on. The ball reacts to the flippers near perfectly. Trick shots, and saves can happen just like in real life. The ball can drain straight down the center or to the side just like the real thing.

The tables....

I own 12 tables as I wtite this review. I pick my tables based on playing the demo version that the game allows. I have played real life tables since the days they where more mechanical then electronic. I can tell enough, from the demo's all of the tables are heavly tested, not just for skill level but play style as well. I have found several tables that meet my taste. If you enjoy pinball you will find something in your flavor as well.


PRO's:
No quarters lost at the arcade.
Physics are spot on. Ball behaves very much like real life pinball.
Flippers are responsive, and won't wear out with time.
Full controller support (Highly Recommend)
Tables are exciting and themed.
Tables are well tested for playability.
Game is highly polished.
Adjustable screen orientation. (portrait mode)
Possible to demo tables before buying.

CON's:
No glass pops or free game pops.
Some tables may be a little busy or flashy.
No old school tables. with more targets, slots, pockets, or bumpers.
Some of the camera follows can be abrubt and distracting.
Demo's shorter then I want. (but aceptable)
Some tables not available outside of packs.
Start screen displays all availabe DLC.

My only peeve, is the my last con. I don't want to be told my collection is incomplete, if I don't want that table. There should be a tab to display available content. I only want to see my own collection on the title screen. Ding 1 point for this infraction only.

9/10

reviewText: I've mostly played this game on PS3 where it's called Zen Pinball, but it's pretty much the same here, and I've played it a lot.  The tables are almost without exception of excellent design.  The physics are great, there's a lot of view modes, the high score tables are great, new tables come out regularly, graphics and sound is awesome. I just can't say enough positive things about this game.  I'd never really played pinball before playing this, apart from putting in som quarters for a short game in rl pinball machines when I was a kid.  I didn't expect to get this addicted to it or that it would be so much fun.  Even though you'll suck at first most likely, if you just try to improve your own score and understand the tables you'll improve a lot pretty fast and then addiction kicks in.  If you can compete with a friend or more it's even more fun. You may not expect it or know it yet, but chances are you'll love it!

reviewText:
Pinball taken to 11

Theres really not alot to say about the game play of Pinball FX2.  Its pinball. but its one of the best virtual pinball games i've ever played.  It has a sleek presentation, and the game play and physics feel really good.  and since its not a reality the table aren't bound by physical limitations so you can have things like people flying around the table or explosions that add to the presntation and polish.  I also like how even with these larger than life elements it still feels like pinball. no stupid gimicks. just a ball and flippers.

Now i'm talking about the over all experince here.  Some tables in the game are better than others and that will vary depending on what kind of pinball elements you like and how appealing a particlar tables theme is to you.  but reguardless there are a large variety of table you can purcahse and each one is will have the same level of quality, polish and presentation.

If you need your pinball fix this is a good option

reviewText:
I have only played this for a little while.
When I was little and Windows XP came with Pinball, it was one of the only games I played. I loved it because it was something to do...

Now here we are a decade later and I find this game. While it is annoying you don't have more than one table free, it is pretty realistic. The UI is slick, the themes are pretty accurate, and there's something about it that gives you nostalgia. Now, I'm not old enough to remember Arcade Pinballs but I have played a real game before. This is pretty accurate to the formula. If it were any more realistic it'd be scary.

Oh and a plus you can get the Portal table half off if you own the games.

reviewText: It is Pinball taken to its next logical evolutionary step. I can not find enough words to heap on the praise this game and its many tables deserve and believe me, I tried hard. I have a Thesaurus open in front of me and it just isn't helping. The tables are bright, engaging and tremendously fun. The sound effects and themes chosen are fantastic and it combines all the amazing fun and real terror of real pinball. Losing your ball is as disappointing as it is in real life! Can't beat that! The Star Wars Tables are great, and the new Portal Pinball table looks well worth acquiring. If only they would do a Jurassic Park table, just like the Data East one from 1993. One can dream! Get your favorite tables, put your quarters away and play till real life gets in the way!

reviewText:
Pinball FX2 is frankly the best pinball game you will find on Steam. I'll keep this review short since it's just pinball and quite frankly there's little to say, but anyone interested in having a solid arcade feeling pinball experience should get this game.

PROS



Fun


Good Selection of tables


Solid Feeling Controls, everything feels responsive and you never feel like you missed a ball thanks to a delayed flipper or anything else.


Multiple table aesthetics to suit anyone's taste. Want an underwater themed table? It's there. Want a wild west themed table? It's there. Want a space themed table? It's there.


Multiple camera angles to play around with so anyone can adjust the camera to their playstyle if they want a larger view of the table or just want to follow the ball. Plus they look cool and can be used to switch things up if it gets boring.


The music and sounds for each table are nice


It looks pretty



CONS


The game gives you one free table but you'll quickly get bored of that and want to buy some other tables which frankly feel like a rip. Most tables are three dollars which isn't that bad for the amount of quality you get with these tables, but still feels a little bit too expensive. I would just drop 10$ on the core pack which gives you some of the best tables in the game and buy the others which seem of interest to you. While not a big flaw for a free game, it's something to consider.



Many of the tables are promotional tables for Star Wars, Marvel, or Football(Soccer to us Americans). While no-one is forcing you to buy these tables, they take up the majority of Tables offered by the shop and seem to be a lesser quality than most other tables. This could just be my personal preference, but the Venom table is my least touched table out of all the tables I own. I hear the Football(Soccer) tables are weird also.


Lack of Windowed mode. This is really a game that needs windowed mode, but lacks it


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you have any interest in Pinball or are a Pinball enthusiast pick this game up, you wont be disappointed.

reviewText: One of the most popular pinball games. Follow your senses and let the days of the Star Wars series pinball machines get your light saber fingers moving. Or kick off a soccer game with your friends and then go play with South Park tables. No, then sit back and try your hand at the many other tables found in this collection of fun tables. Challenge your frineds to beat you or play with them in multiplayer mode for instant action. The more friends you have that play this game the higher your score will be in the end with shared point accumulator. This is not a slow paced game, eye and hand coordination is key. Being drunk, high or under the influence will not help your game. Distractions like children and pets can bring your game down so try to give them something else to do while you play. Enjoy your game and don't forget about the real world. Stop, go outside, stretch and visit the bathroom before returning to the game. Please pause the game if your child needs you and remember this is only a game.

reviewText:
Pinball FX 2 is not a realistic pinball experience, but it's equally addictive and has a charm of its own.
Pros:

- The FREE table is fantastic and gives a great indication of what PinballFX has to offer.
- The price of each table is very reasonable, especially when compared to other pinball games.
- Really great mixture of original and acquired IP tables.
- Great visuals, nice graphic styling.
- Deeply designed tables, even more so than many real tables.
- Cabinet support (if you're fancy enough!)
- Table guides that actually take you around the table, allowing you to form a stratergy.
- Leaderboards.
- Very stable build.

Cons

- Ball feels a bit light/weightless, not like real tables.
-  The UI is a bit of an eyesore.
- The audio is a bit too 'clean' for a pinball table, bit of a strange gripe but hey.
- Some audio can be repetitive and annoying sometimes (South Park is one of the worst for this)

***NOTICE TO ZEN***

Although tables based on existing intellectual properties are great, you should not neglect to continue to create originals! Some of the most enjoyable tables are your own (Paranormal, Sorcerer's Lair, Epic Quest).

Tables with IP's sell much better I'm sure, but It would be awesome if we got another original once in a while!

Thanks for making a great game!

reviewText:
Watch out for this one.  It sucks you in with a free table that can easily kill an hour of your time.  Once you're hooked, new tables are $2.50/ea.

The actual game?  Fun, fun, fun.  Lots of ramps, gizmos, and assorted goodies.   Some of the tables have mini sub-tables that open up when you reach a certain goal.

One really nice feature is a high score list that includes scores of your Steam friends.

reviewText:
REGARDING THE EULA: I looked further into it. It's been changed again.
The ZEN Services may include third party dynamic behavioral in-game advertising technology which enables tailored advertising to be temporarily uploaded into the ZEN Services on your device and replaced while you are online. For further information please read the Privacy Policy.
Now you may be thinking that the game will be full of ads. Nope, that's not the case. I'd say it's rather limited, actually. It's mostly because of all the promotional pinball tables that you can buy (e.g. Star Wars tables, Marvel tables). No ads popping into your face. There's really nothing to worry about.

Whether it is still collecting information like your location/IP addrees, hell if I know. Most of this only applies to you IF you open a ZEN account. Now I'm not sure whether the game automatically creates a ZEN account for you using your Steam account information, which it can access of course (like almost every game).

Now about the game:

I've been longing for a good Pinball game since Pinball Fantasy on the Amiga. This game is pretty much what I wanted. Even the ball physics work almost the same way as in Pinball Fantasy.

There was 1 huge problem I had with this game, which was input lag. I found a fix for it on the community formus.

As for the cameras, the 3rd and the last camera setting works for (since I'm used to Pinball Fantasy), the rest are indeed pretty bad though. Most of them are set pretty low which gives a very skewed view on the table.

As for the tables themselves, looks like the original tables are the best although also a bit cheesy (but hey, if classic pinball tables are your thing, then you'll love them). The Star Wars tables and most of the promotional ones, although they look good, most of them are pretty boring. I absolutely recommend the Portal table though. It's on of the most creative tables out there.

The pricing seems reasonable to me (I mean, they could've asked for like 30 dollars and include 4-5 tables as usual with pinball games). Most of them also come in packs, so you can save a bit + there's always steam sales.

reviewText: Everyone loves pinball, I used to be a pinball freak. However, Out of the 20+ pinball fx 2 tables I got in the humble bundle (for $6), only about 10 I would play again, and 5 I'd want to master to get a good score at (Iron Man, Spooky house, Temple, epic loot, tesla). There's no tables from Pinball FX 1 that I can see, and none of the tables I've played in 2 top the red car racing one that came with PBFX1. That said, as a game, its flawless pinball action, everyone should own this game.

reviewText: Pinball FX2 is the sequel of Pinball FX for the XBox 360, thus you can play this too with the XBox 360-controller. Pinball FX2 is a great example of very cool pinball-simulators. Although the itself is free, you have to buy pinball tables first, because that's only way to actually play the game. But don't worry, those pesky microtransactions are wourth your money. The tables go around 3 bucks, and a collection of tables goes for 7 bucks (a few tables) to 11 bucks (around 5 tables). I recommend buying the Portal-, Football/Soccer-, Marvel-, and cartoon-tables (South Park, Family Guy, et cetra). Great design, good graphics (even for my crappy laptop, without lag), nice table layout. One con is, again, the fact that you have to BUY tables. 7,5/10

reviewText:
Pinball FX2 has some fun moments, but the developer is misguided and with the latest update, has shanked it's players and has really lost focus on the direction the game is going.

Anyone who plays this game seriously has saved games, because you can't possibly finish a good run in one sitting, they go for 5+ hours and a lot longer in some cases. Zen decided to ninja an update that destroyed all saves across all tables and didn't warn the community ahead of time, even though it was known it would destroy saves. The condescending pop-up message confirms this.
Top it off with the random crashes means you don't have a lot to look forward to other than frustration and wasting your time.

The direction of all the new tables is this: Disney / Marvel. Zombies.    Don't expect much else. It's clear that the team has given up trying to be original, and like, say, Hollywood, just rehashes others' ideas, believing it will get a bigger response based on nostalgia and moronic fanboy response.
Speaking of fanboys...
The community has some good people but don't expect much give and take. Don't expect to be critical of anything without a bevy of uninvited losers with pacman avatars to go all fanboy attack on your comments / screenshots / whatever.

This is ultimately the fallout of the fun in the game, in the long term. The people get annoying and if you don't tow the company's line, you will be bashed. Not by everyone, but you can't get away from the truly douchey people.

Quality is hit or miss on the newer tables;  i.e. the Star Wars line are poorly exectued with a couple of exceptions and I expect this general trend to continue, as they seem to be going for style over substance.

Do not buy. Pinball Arcade is a decent alternative for now.
voteText: 22 of 48 people (46%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The four tables I purchased are derivative and have either an odd number of flippers, or asymmetric upper flippers, that are only useful for very specific and difficult shots (e.g. ball lock on Biolab). The tables also all suffer from strange bumps from the slingshots and sometimes the tip of the flippers that fire the ball right down the centre out-ramp (drain) before any reaction can be made; they try to address this problem with a ball save feature, but it happens too often and quickly becomes demoralizing. Also, the scoring feels off" or disproportionate and takes forever to get a score above 10 million on any of the tables. The only success I've had is with the free table and I had to play for almost an hour to get 230 million and it became more of a chore than fun. Once I got that high score I "retired" the table and haven't played it since. The graphics are amazing
recommended: but flashy graphics does not a good game make. I found Pinball Arcade to be have generally better physics and game-play. I won't be spending any more money on this game."

reviewText:
This is, hands down, the best pinball experience you can have without an actual pinball machine. The tables are fantastic with tons of scoring options and the challenges and missions are lots of fun. This game is great for casual fans looking for a quick pinball fix and hardcore fans trying to move their way up the leaderboard.

I can see where die-hard pinball fanatics wouldn't be into pinball FX2. The game's biggest downfall IMO is the physics aren't actual, real life, perfectly emulated, like one would find on a real pinball table. They aren't perfect, but they are really really close and the best you can find on a digitized pinball platform.

As fun as this game is, it becomes so much better when you have a friend who is competing with you taking away the high scores on a table challenging you to improve your game in order to take them back.

reviewText:
I don't usually play pinball games. In fact the only ones I did play were 20 years ago on my Amiga (Pinball Fantasies, Pinball Dreams and Pinball Wizard). However, recently I bought a couple of Pinball FX2 tables in a humble bundle. I have played 5 tables so far. Here are my impressions.

The good is:
- It's free! You can try one table and then decide if you want more.
- There are a lot of different tables available in wide range of styles.

The bad is:
- Paying for each table feels like a collectible game.
- The difference between the tables is mostly cosmetic. This is probably an inherent problem of pinball itself.
- The sound effects, especially the ones containing movie quotes and such, get old very quickly.
- However, the most important problem for me is that FX2 does not feel like a real pinball table. The ball is seemingly weightless as it makes no sound when it touches a wall and it sometimes changes direction in an unrealistic way.
- Also, there is a noticeable delay between pressing the button and the flippers moving, which is the worst problem a game like this can have. How can you mess up controls that basically consist of two button?

All in all I would not recommend the game. Feel free to try it, but be critical and remember that the other tables are not that different from the free one.

reviewText:
I love pinball and have played the silver ball for many years. This is one of my favorite games on Xbox 360, so when I got my PC hooked up with Steam, I had to get it.

Some of the games are better than others, just like real pinball machines. However, I've aways felt that Zen Studios has put more effort into the graphics and effects and on some games I wonder if anyone has actually played the game to see what it played like. Some of the tables seem like they are designed to last thirty seconds, when a ball goes down the tubes without a flipper play, I mean, how much fun is that? Also, there are bugs and gameplay problems that are never fixed and never will be. If an FX2 table comes out with a bug, it will never be fixed. High scores jave been deleted weekly from leaderboards and in the rare tournament that they have, the results may deleted and never posted again. Zen Studios say they are a small studio and are working as hard as they can, but problems are never fixed. Never.

I've only played FX2 on Steam for about an hour, but it's enough to know I won't be buying any more tables than I already have. First off, there is no windowed mode. I can't move the game from my computer monitor to my HDTV. FX2 has great graphics, probably the best thing about the game, but when you play on a small screen, you can's see anything. I have a 23 1920 x 1080 computer monitor
date: too many details to see clearly
recommended: the game would be way better at 1080p or 720p on a 32" HDTV. Also
hoursPlayed: the Microsoft wireless controller is disconnected from the game at random

reviewText:
I can't say that I've played this much - only the recently introduced 'free' table - owing to the fact that for some reason (my Nvidia optimus gaming laptop w/GTX675M, or the programming itself) the flipper response is very laggy. Hell, Space Cadet on XP worked better for me than Pinball FX2. And since I couldn't find any options to adjust framerates or resolution to optimize the experience, I have uninstalled this game and will not be coming back until maybe such time as I work with discrete only graphics or we all evolve to on-die graphics.

I'm aware that this isn't much of a basis for a recommendation, but if I can't play the game, I can't recommend it, even if I really wanted to love this (as I did really like Full Tilt Pinball 1 and 2 back in the day).

Short summary: if you have Optimus (or maybe even AMD switchable graphics), this one could be a lemon for you.

reviewText: Great game, iffy port.  Picked this up when it was on sale as it was cheap, but found out after the fact that it's missing the touchscreen integration that the Windows Store version of the same app has.  This is the fourth or fifth time I've been bit by Xen Studios's inability to do things cross platform (or even same platform) well.  Doesn't work with touchscreens, won't work on my Surface Pro in any playable fashion, and I've already bought all of this content on both my PS3 and iPhone/iPad that won't transfer between.\n\nIf you haven't ever owned this game at all before, it's worth picking up.  If you already own it on another platform or own tables somewhere else, stay far away.  If you played the demo through Windows Store and liked it, buy through Windows Store, do NOT buy through Steam, they are NOT the same game.

reviewText:
I love a good pinball game.

Unfortunately this is nothing like a good pinball game.  There is one 'free' table which changes occasionally (every month or so) and there are 21 other tables to play which lock you out after 60 seconds or 500,000 points.  When the trial is over, you are prompted to buy the board or get kicked out.

Micro transactions are the pits.

The paddle controls are wooden and the responsiveness of the tables leaves a lot to be desired (Just don't tilt.)  Honestly, if you are looking for a quick game of pinball, then this 1.5GB monstrosity, which is marked as ‘free’, isn’t it.

The only positive elements to mention are the single free" board
date: which is not terrible.  Purchasing the 'add-on' boards would get expensive quickly.  This is too bad really because the trial boards look interesting but 60 seconds isn't enough time to even get a feel for them and is really just frustrating.\n\nI can't recommend this game

reviewText:
First of all, do not be fooled, this is NOT a free game and it sure is not cheap. It costs over $40 to buy complete, as it is offered one table at a time. The better tables cost as much as a complete 3-years old game on sale whereas the not so good tables are cheaper. And now for the bad news.


Problem No.1: the perspective is all wrong and there is no way to fix it. The back half of the table (including the back flippers in most cases) are hidden from view. You hear sounds, you see some movement yet you have no idea what's going on. There are ways to give a forced 3D view to a simulated pinball table; unfortunately the developers missed the ball in all of them ;).

Problem No.2: the physics are screwed up. A pinball game is by definition a game of split-second decisions and unpredictability (yet consistent) gravitomagnetic reactions. So, I cannot imagine how anyone can claim of having fun with a pinball game that is inconsistent in its physics.

Problem No.3: the graphics are forcibly low and the resolution is not modifiable. A barely playable game that is not even a eye-candy?

I am sorry but I cannot recommend this to anyone. Microsoft’s Space Cadet (not to mention Austin Powers Pinball) were far better pinball games. In all honesty, I have had more fun with pinball games on my smartphone. And I have a... Windows phone!

reviewText:
I play this game a hell of a lot, at least by my standards, and have some 150 hours+ played... so you'd think with me playing this game so frequently, i must like it a lot, right? WRONG!

This game is pretty much gaming heroin, it's got me well and truly hooked, and that is the only reason i continue playing. And i mean the ONLY reason, because despite having all the DLC tables, i vehemently detest every second i'm playing this thing. This game subjects you to unbearable frustration unlike any other. For every go you enjoy because you do well, there are around 50 goes where it makes you look and feel like you've never started the game before, you do so badly. Yes there is skill involved, but also huge amounts of luck. The number of times a potential new best score is terminated because the ball gets shot straight into an out-lane or straight between the central flippers without you having the chance to do a single thing is ridiculous. In my 150+ hours i have NEVER, not once, had a go where at least one ball wasn't totally wasted.

If you do something crazy, like... oh i dunno... actually not play this game for 1 day, then that is long enough to ensure you become so rusty you play like a total first-timer. Or if you do something truly masochistic, like play this game every day, it will still go in cycles so you once again go back to playing like a total first-timer. Except, of course, now you have your own personal high scores that show to you how well you should be at this game, as you struggle to barely reach 5% of that high score in your next 50+ attempts.

This game is NOT fun, it is NOT enjoyable, but you WILL constantly play it because it hooks you almost immediately. The base game with first table is free and you can try all other available tables for a short time before buying them as DLC's. But spare yourself endless frustration and don't try it! I hate this game with a passion and wish i had never found it on here!

And before people comment saying i only hate this game because i'm crap at it, with only 2 exceptions every one of my high scores on all current tables (so on 41 of the 43 tables at the time of writing) are within the top 10%, so my intense loathing of this game is nothing to do with me being crap at it.

reviewText:
Too much latency on controls.

When you press the flipper buttons, there is a little bit of delay before the flippers react. It may seem little, but it's too much, and it makes the game unplayable for anyone who actually enjoys playing pinball.

There nothing wrong with my setup, my computer or anything on my end. The game is the problem. Some people may not notice the latency, but it's there for them too.

Therefore I cannot recomend this game.

reviewText:
I've always loved pinball. As a child, I'd always gravitate to them and feed as many quarters in their gullet as my parents would provide. I loved the sounds, the feel of the flippers, the glittering LED screens and flashing lights. The time was over too quickly. So when I saw the free-to-play Pinball FX2 hit Steam, I downloaded it immediately.

It's easy to understand the notion of FX2: a digital platform for tables that are too fantastical for the real world. It's a great idea. But it doesn't quite deliver. The tables are imaginative, bright and colorful, and sometimes unique. Something is missing, though. Something that's hard to explain. I think it all boils down to three main problems: sound, physics, and table design.

Part of the splendor of pinball is the pings, pongs, bings, clanks, and bangs of the steel bearing flying around the arena. In large part, those tiny sounds are simply not present. You hit a target, and you hear nothing. Some flippers don't flip. The ball pangs off of a bumper, and the sound is stunted and dull. Even the ball itself sounds like a hollow piece of hardwood. It's not right. It's not the pinball I know.

The sound is bad, but the physics add another layer of non-realism to the escapade. The ball tends to accelerate too quickly. When it hits a lower bumper, it barely makes it to the adjacent. It's as if the ball itself is tired. If you hit a ramp without enough speed, there's no hangtime. It almost immediately reverses direction and comes back at you with full force. It feels completely wrong.

The tables generally look spactacular at first glance. Characters are animated, the lights are in the right places, and there are decorative nuances that look great. It's mostly window dressing. Once the ball is launched, you immediately notice problems. Most tables lack a proper skillshot, or the ball simply shoots across the table into a boring location only to be flipped back up into a myriad of lazy ramps. And boy do the designers love ramps. Several tables are almost completely composed of them. Ramps are a core part of pinball, but there needs to be balance. You need targets, flippers, spinners, bumpers, and above all: goals.

All of the tables have goals. They are just hard - or frustrating - to find. They need to be more obvious. It's no fun to throw the ball around for 10 minutes without hearing a single mission from the horribly acted announcers. When you manage to find one, they don't pay off. There's no feel of advancement.

I had high hopes. Probably too high. Pinball FX2 didn't deliver.

There is a game, though, for my fellow pinball fans: Pinball Arcade (also on Steam). You get one table free and are able to try any of the rest until you hit a reasonable score cap. Each table is painstakingly digitalized from a real, beloved machine. And it shows. The care taken into recreation is obvious at every turn. The physics are -perfect-. The tables, in general, are a complete blast to play. The snippets of history attached before you play a table makes you fully understand the attention the developers put into the game of pinball. They love it in real life and wanted to express it digitally. They fully succeeded. The tables are pricy, but entirely worth the money.

Play Pinball Arcade. Don't play FX2.

reviewText:
Tables are sometime a little confused and they are quite expensive

Some free software give a better physic emulation perception (VP and FP)

Table layouts lack diversity like we could find in the shareware DOS Epic pinball/Silverball pinballs.

I got this through  Humble Bundle...  Maybe  with  a good discount (like XMAS and such) it could be worth  its money but when  at full price,  it's clearly exagerated.

Plus : global ranking system, many tables, good eye candy
Minus : expensive, not the best physics rendering
It may be interresting  at  a casual  level.

reviewText: I would really like to recommend this game but I just can't. reviewText:
This is probably the most blatant use of free-to-play" I've ever seen. You can only play one table. That's it. Just one. At least Pinball Arcade also threw in a free table you could play for a month. But this one gives you no sort of freebie. And the one table you CAN play is rather bleh IMO.

I played the table a couple times and it got boring quickly. The voices are obnoxious and the music was kinda bland. Sure there were extra "mini tables" but I got ejected back to the main table before I could even figure out what I was supposed to do! Give me a redo for the love of God!

The fact that all of the tables cost over $100 just makes me want to bang my head on a wall. I could use that money to buy all the games on my Wishlist and still have money left over!

All I want out of Steam is a non-demo free game that doesn't contain microtransactions to unlock other features. I'm very low on funds and I'm trying to use it wisely
date: but is a Steam game that doesn't ask for money every five seconds too hard to make? If you want a decent Steam pinball game
recommended: go with Pinball Arcade. Not this Marvel-whoring
hoursPlayed: money-grabbing game."

reviewText: They ALMOST get it right, with one game breaking problem: The simulator doesn't respond realistically as far as ball spin is concerned. It's too sensitive to it, making the ball behave in unexpected and unpredictable ways, resulting in more of a game of chance than a game of skill (which is what pinball is supposed to be).
